Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body:
Speaking of positioning, what formation do you think would work best against Bayern? I was thinking 4-3-1-2, with Licht or Cuadrado at RB, Chiellini and Bonucci at CB, and Evra/Sandro at LB. Then maybe change the 3 man midfield up, and put Khedira, Marchisio and Sturaro in the middle of the park, and then (I know this is going to sound stupid) put Pogba at CAM, then have Dybala and Mandzukic up top. Morata can come on later, but it’s important to have players with knowledge about Bayern start the match.
Don’t hate me, please
(Just realized that Sandro played against Bayern last season, so i edited the comment. Sorry)

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body: Anything with a four man backline so that their wingers don’t have space. I like a 4-3-1-2 with Dybala and Mandzu as strikers. Pereyra as TQ. Pogba, Khedira and Marchisio as midfielders. Licht, Bonucci, Chellini and Sandro as our four man backline.

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body:
There was a penalty earlier on Medel clearly touching the ball inside the area with his arm (and the referee was like five meters away watching the ball).
There was a red on Murillo for the foul that led to the penalty.
Unsurprisingly, the Curva was singing "Tagliavento figlio di puttana" (Tagliavento son of a bitch).
Leaving this aside, not a particularly brilliant game, but not bad either. I would like a larger win to secure the final, let’s see what the boys can produce in the second half.

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body:
So far so good, a few threatening moments from Inter, but nothing extremely serious (no surprise when you play 3 frikkin defensive midfielders-.-)
Morata playing with exuberance and Mandzukic working his socks off defensively. Medel giving Marchisio a bit of a hard time with his energetic pressing but IL Principino dealing with it quite well.

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body:
- Morata has got to spend less time lying on the piTech. It’s great he got his goal, now quit that shit.
- Marchisio is delightfully ambidextrous. Just felt like stressing that point.
- Pogba meh tonight.
- Poor Neto won’t have to make a save at all in CI.
- You know inter has got a creativity problem when you realise their most inventive midfielder is Gary Medel…
- Cuadrado: ok, this ones a bit longer:
We know he has problems finishing his plays on the final third, but most will agree that he is great initiating them. His first 30-40m are direct, fast and disorienting for the opposition, and his early crosses aren’t half bad. Consider this, plus the fact that lately he has been quite solid in defence…..So, this makes me wonder that he may have what it takes to be a good fullback. Should we try him our when we go 4 again?

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body:
no one deliberately aims to hurt people.
No disrespect, I been around here for a long time, also earlier on theOFFSIDE, and there has been more than a few incidents that hurt not just me, more than once, exactly because of wording.
People getting judged on both objective and subjective outlooks is a symptom around here, I feel.
Why not put that to end?

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body:
…it is just a thought that comes to me whenever I hear a player compared to Alessandro, nothing against the original post.
I am not generally big on players being compared to bigger historical names. But with Del Piero in particular I always feel there is so much more that needs to be done to earn a comparison with him, and at least half of it has nothing to do with what you do on the pitch!
That being said…Dybala…what a little bundle of joy that kid is!

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body:
But in all honesty, I don’t get/understand the hate towards Padoin…..
Everyone, including himself, knows of his limitation.. the only time he’s been a burden on Juve was in that game away to Roma.. Allegri should have never played him in Marchisio’s role…. but even then Allegri had little options.. and Padoin, the soldier that he is, does what he is asked to do. Now whether how good he can be at it is an entirely different story. But he is always reliable and sound tactically.

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Inter Milan
Comment Body:
Agreed. Say what you will about him, but he’s an intelligent, hardworking player that almost never makes mistakes. Also knows his role and is versatile.
In my opinion, events like Frosinone scoring last minute wouldn’t happen if he were there. He’s one of the better players closing out games by drawing fouls and slowing the pace to run down the clock.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
He hasn’t convinced me on the physical level. He’s the shy eloquent kind of player who would avoid physical collisions. Kinda reminds me of Pirlo. In the modern game you need 11 players to be physically strong, especially advanced midfielders that can defend opposition attacks and end them way before they form a threat.
But surely I prefer him over the likes of Hernanes.
Someone mentioned before Saponara. Yes I think Saponara is the best local Italian choice to pick up from. He is younger, more dynamic and I was impressed seeing him bully opposition defenders.

I like Vazquez but Saponara is better in every way
Eh, that’s debatable. Vazquez is a much better dribbler than Saponara, and probably has better vision and passing as well. Saponara is probably stronger and better at shaking off defenders. Saponara is a very talented player and I like him, but I think Vazquez is better than him.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Title: The age really isn't an issue.
Comment Body:
That’s still 3-4 seasons of the best physical years of his life, with 1-2 seasons of still really good physical conditions. It’s obviously nice to get someone in the 22-25 year range, but a 27-year-old with the intentions of being an immediate starter is a perfectly fine transfer age.
I haven’t really spent enough time watching him to say whether he’s worth the price tag, though.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body: Wait – serious? Juventini around the world, from the smallest blogs to the actual boardroom, have identified a need at trequartista. Aside from Pereyra (who we regrettably havent seen much of this season), we have exactly 0 players for that position. As we saw last season, Max organizes a team pretty well if he has the pieces on hand. I think we could benefit hugely from an actual trequartista who is A) experienced w Serie A, B) a good sub for Pereyra (if he ever gets back onto the pitch), C) a good pairing with Dybala already, D) trying to prove himself to Conte to make France 2016.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
Huh? He’s definitely Juve material. Excellent dribbling, very good vision and passing ability, good shot from distance as well. Not to mention his relationship with Dybala.
And we definitely need a player like him, or at least a player of his ilk. I know Cosmo likes to blabber on about how much we need a TQ, and it gets very grating, but there’s definitely truth to what he says. Vazquez would be perfect in this case.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
I was completely against this last year or so when we were quite heavily linked to him. But I’ve watched him a couple of times this year and to me he’s the real deal, someone right in the prime of their career. He’s a real throwback to the natural trequartista of yesteryear.
Clearly has immense technical quality, but he’s got a great physicality/size about him, the way he’s built is just ideal. I can envision him just having his presence felt around the pitch by that alone. He’s got that Pogba sort of arrogance, gliding across the pitch, which can make him seem lazy at times (which from what I have seen, he isn’t).
If we are looking for someone to come in and make an immediate impact for the next 3-4 years, I’d be all for this move. I genuinely think he’s ready to burst onto the scene at a big club. If we’re taking a more long term look, clearly Saponara is the name being thrown around. Whatever it is, options are damn scarce, other than Franco and Ricky, I’m struggling to come up with names. Yunus Malli’s the only left field name coming to my head…but we’d never target him.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body: Oh yeah and this Lucas Lima guy, but I’ve only seen him on FM…where he looks fooooooooooooookin’ redonculous

Comment Body: A move for Gundogan can potentially fuck up our investments in Lemina and Sturaro. Too many MFers.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body: Once again, Lemina is not Juventus owned. While Sturaro is, bringing in Gundogan and letting Lemina return to OM wouldn’t be a loss at all, imo. Ilkay is more talented and has performed in more important moments – surely that outweighs the potential some see in Lemina. I don’t think if Gundogan were to arrive that it would hurt Sturaro’s development. We have 3 midfield positions and 8 CMFs currently, only 4 of whom routinely see playing time. Now, some of that is due to injury and fitness issues but I don’t think that Sturaro would have trouble finding playing time after Pogba, Claudio, Sami, and Ilkay (if he arrives).

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again

If Gundogan arrives, Sturaro will be 5th in line. a 33 year old might be ok with that but i’m not sure Sturaro would be ok with that. He has admirers too, unlike Luca Brown!

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
Riccardo Saponara is a very talented player and his performances over the last year and a half proves it. Saponara could potentially succeed at Juve but has always seemed to me to be a player full of hard running and guile instead of flair. Having seen him play for Empoli on a number of occassions I would prefer Vazquez as he appears to possess better dribbling skills and an ability to hold onto the ball. Juventus have enough hard runners at present and need a player in the TQ role who can take on opponents and make the difference when the attack is nullified.
Vazquez vs Saponara

Serie A 14/15 37 10 11 7.74 Serie A 14/15 17 5 6 7.02
Serie A 15/16 20 3 5 7.61 Serie A 15/16 18 7 4 7.14
The above shows App, Goals, Assists, Av. Ratings. I’m sure one of you guys can produces something more comparable and impressive such as a comparison of successful take ons, pass completion rates etc

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
Look at these . .
15/16
Vazquez 80.4% passing average with 2 key passes, 2.6 long balls, 0.2 through balls per game and 1.1 crosses. 3.6 dribbles per game.
Saponara 74.5% passing average with 2.7 key passes, 1.1 long balls, 0.1 through balls per game and 0.2 crosses. 2.2 dribbles per game.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
The numbers suggest Vazquez would be more comfortable in a deep[er] position i.e. in the hole, but with drifting tendencies.
Vazquez also considerably more tackles per game.
Saponara’s numbers are good for a centrally-roaming CAM, just a little low on accuracy.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
Saponara has enjoyed stability in playing in a fixed formation of 4312 behind Pucciarelli and Maccarone while Vazquez has had to showcase his talents under difficult circumstances of tactical upheavals brought by managerial changes and a mad president. More reason to think he will blossom at Juve with Dybala in a stable team with a winning mentality.
For those discussing the age difference in the comments above, its only 3 years. Ricky is 24 and Vazquez will be 27 soon.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
The only thing that bothers me about Vazquez is Camoranesi’s outlook on the player. I suspect it may be true. Every time I wanted to take a look at Vazquez he has disappointed. With Saponara, you can tell the kid got unpolished skills . .
I’m 50-50 about the both of them, to be honest, but I wouldn’t be mad if we got either. We need that CAM.

The pickle are the defensive numbers, Vasquez is a way bigger factor on DEF than Saponara with 3.6 tackles per game vs Saponara with 0.5.

Comment Body: Normally there’s a negative correlation with passing rate and average pass distance, but Vazquez is superior in both areas. Saponara does create a lot more chances (nearly a full chance per 90), which would indicate riskier passes, but that could easily also be because Empoli holds more possession on average.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body: The 75% passing accuracy kind of makes sense for Saponara’s playing style, the ground he covers. Predominantly central.

Article Title: Palermo playmaker Franco Vazquez would like to be teammates with Paulo Dybala again
Comment Body:
Very hard to compare statistics in a team sport. Empoli play decidedly different football than Palermo and their teams have big turnovers year after year. It is hard to say that Vasquez assists numbers are not affected by Dybala’s departure for example.
I think when it comes to the football they can play I would say it is roughly the same. Faster or slower I don’t think that really matters so much. However, attitude and personality are huge. You can’t tell me that Ballotelli is not immensely talented, but he will never be a success. I just don’t see Vasquez as the player to connect our midfield with our attack. With Saponara I am more hopeful.
With that being said, Saponara will need to be given time to grow and that is unlikely if he comes as our first choice TQ. I still think that bringing a big name (Mkhitaryan is my pick) would be the way to go.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Inter Milan match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Coppa Italia
Comment Title: Nice formation that just needs minor changes.
Comment Body:
1- Neto will play instead of Buffon, which is why we bought him in the first place.
2- Evra played last match so he definitely needs some rest. Plus we are going to need Sandro’s cutting edge.
3- Losing Pogba and Khedira in one "heavy weight" match will weaken the chemistry of our midfield. I do trust Asamoah, however I would prefer if we went with Pogba in the first half and then eased in Asamoah in the second. We need to start the match strongly and take an early lead. (Pogba can rest in the Chievo match)
4- I would go with Manzukic instead of Dybala in the first half to bully the physical defense of Inter. Then introduce Dybala in the second half as fresh speedy legs when their defense slows down gradually. Morata should play the 90 minutes because he is well rested and needs to find himself again.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Inter Milan match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Coppa Italia
Comment Body:
Frankly, I’m not that fond of the 4-3-3. One of our worst games these season was played in that formation. I still prefer the 3-5-2 because of the following downsides of the 4-3-3:
1- Cuadrado won’t offer Manzu any proper service because he likes to cut in himself, whch results in him losing the ball most of the time.
2- When Morata plays as a winger he drifts apart and goes too wide, which keeps him out of action. We need Morata closer to the post so he can have more scoring chances or at least provide something to Manzu. Not mentioning that Morata will be wasted on the wing because we’d have an already active left side with Pogba and Sandro.
3- Licht is among the ones who need to rest. I would go with a 3 man defense with Rugani or a 4 man defense with Caceres.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Inter Milan match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Coppa Italia
Comment Body:
I’m also not a fan of the 4-3-3 with our current players, but one of our best games (against Sevilla) has been done using the 4-3-3… so..
Oh, and I definitely prefer it over the 3-5-2 (I think most of you know that already)

Article Title: Juventus vs. Inter Milan match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Coppa Italia
Comment Body: This.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Inter Milan match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Coppa Italia
Comment Body:
I’m of the opinion that while the CI does not hold the same significance as the Scudetto race or CL, derbies, whether its the local Turin, Derby d’Italia or any one of them, should not be treated like trivial matches regardless of the competition. Especially this year when Inter actually managed to not be terrible for a change. Allegri seems to be respecting the CI this year but that may seem that way since our depth is good enough so "B team" isn’t even that much of a downgrade, Marchisio replacementexcluded.
Hell, Juve vs Inter in the second hlaf of last year’s season frustrated me because we never gave a fuck. The Scudetto was ours so match was lifeless. That said, we got the Morata sunglasses celebration so that’s good.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Inter Milan match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Coppa Italia
Comment Body:
These 2nd stringers all play as if their lives depended on it, and I personally enjoy seeing that. Problem is we don’t get live broadcast of CI games here in Indonesia, and streaming at 2.45 AM with a patchy internet connection on weekdays while I have to go to work in the morning is… Let’s just say it’s not an entirely enticing prospect.
Re: Inter having a bigger chance, don’t be too sure. They also have a high stake to qualify to UCL, so they will still prioritize the league. In fact, I’d say that if they don’t qualify to UCL next season, it’ll be a disaster for them from a financial perspective, simply because they’ve made a lot of financial commitments last summer. Considering the not-so-stellar results that they’ve had in the league these past few games, I’m betting Mancini is in a big dilemma as to whether he wants to play his strongest line up or not.
Besides, last season we played them away with practically our B team after ensuring the league is won, while they used their strongest XI as they were chasing the Europa spot. And we still won.

Comment Body:
"For now I must think about keeping Palermo up, then one day I’d like to play with Dybala again," he told Gazzetta dello Sport.

"He’s a friend and we did great things together at the Rosanero.

"The national team? Of course I’m hoping for a call up. I respect Conte’s choices but I definitely want to wear the Azzurri shirt again.

"Schelotto? He doesn’t need advice from me, he’s a leader and wants to make his mark.

"My future? First I’ll save Palermo and then we’ll see. I can’t decide whether I go to Juventus, Milan, Inter or another big team"
What would you guys make of a Franco Vazquez coming to Juve?
I think he’s a player of the highest quality and has a unique connection with Dybala but I would much rather have Saponara.

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
I foresee a future in which Gigi reaches 40, realizes he’s still playing at a high level and keeps going. Perhaps he takes it year by year but he just doesn’t seem the type to pull the plug when he’s still ‘got it’.
He’s had moments in the past where it looked like the end may be near — the howler he let in versus Alaba a few years ago was perhaps the clearest example (where he said his dad asked him if he was drunk, lol!) — but he always seems to dig deep and finds another gear. Gigi may put a timeline on things because the press has basically forced him to but us fans should probably not put much stock into his words until and unless a noticeable decline in performance occurs.

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Title: Buffon would make a great coach
Comment Body:
From the article:
"When he looks at pictures of his playing career, Buffon often notes that most of the images are of him with his body off the ground, his frame stretched to its limit as he tries to palm a shot away to safety. There are dives left and dives right, but very few pictures of him with his feet on the ground.
"It’s a metaphor for my life," he said. "This is my way, being in the air. My thoughts are in the air. I’m always dreaming.""
I wish he would stay with Juventus forever but he doesn’t think managing a Serie A club is in his future, looking elsewhere.

Comment Title: These feelings will never go away
Comment Body:
One of the saddest days….
After 19 years with Juventus, bringing the team back and winning the scudetto, Ale wasn’t even given an opportunity to part with his beloved club as the LEGEND he was, the Captain, the reason many boys and girls followed the game.
Whether it was Conte’s ego, Agnelli’s biggest screw up, I really don’t care, this is not Real Madrid, this is Juventus…..the fact of not offering Alessandro Del Piero a chance to renew or decline renewing a contract WAS and STILL REMAINS inexcusable, unjustifiable, indefensible and unforgivable.
I don’t know if it could be somehow made better.

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
So here is my take on it.
A) Lets get this out of the picture as to whether Conte/Allegri had something to do with it or not. They did. Agnelli announced it without ADP knowing about it, if i recall correctly. So they knew what they were doing, and doing it without ADP’s consent (from what i know).
B) Also ,lets forget about money, since ADP has earlier signed a blank cheque for the club ans would have easily done it again.
now, for me the real question is, did they do the right thing or not? and if yes, was the manner in which it was executed right, given the circumstances?
Did they do the right thing or not?
For me, the answer is a yes. In his last 2 years as a juve player, ADP looked like a shadow of the player he was. Every time he had to run, he would stop and look for a killer pass instead. He had lost his legs and was purely relying on his vision and class to get by (not that that’s a bad thing). Now granted his game wasn’t built around speed anymore, but it was becoming a major issue. You can check his stats in his last two seasons. 9 and 8 goals in the two season he was a starter and then 3 under Conte (although i wont count this since he barely feature in the first 11). Add to this the fact that he was the biggest legend the club had ever had, and this had the potential of becoming an issue in the locker room. Remember, ADP is a champ and he had no intention of sitting on the bench. He and his agent made this clear even during the Capello era. I remember back then he was linked in some J-league clubs. So if you keep him, you have to play him. period. Conte wasnt willing (a stand which was vindicated after he wont the league without replying on ADP) and so Agnelli being the head of the organization took the call and bit the bullet for Conte, so to speak. As much as i love ADP, I agree with Agnelli’s call.
B) Was the manner in which it was executed the right way
Right? I dont know. But under the circumstances, there simply was no other way to do it. ADP wouldn’t do it himself. we all knew that. He had offered to sign another blank cheque! So it was up to the management to do it. Now how do do it when you know he wants to play, and the most you can do is offer the bench? Add to this the fact that Gio was about to come back and he DEFINITELY needed space. It had to be Agnelli and Agnelli it was, who made the shock announcement. He did what needed to be done. I would rather see ADP leave the way he did than see him warm the bench for no reason. The fact that ADP still hasnt retired proves that he still wants to play, and this is something Juventus simply couldn’t guarantee him anymore.
Now SHOOOT!

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
I think the problem most people have is Part B).
It definitely wasn’t the best way to do it. I think ADP wanted to keep playing, maybe even at Juve. Approaching this subject would be a delicate issue for the Directors and would need to be handled delicately. It wasn’t. What was the right approach? I don’t know. I do find it surprising that the issue was not discussed at more detail and then ADP found out in a random press conference.
Him finding out by surprise was probably among the worst options IMO.
The fact that ADP still hasnt retired proves that he still wants to play, and this is something Juventus simply couldn’t guarantee him anymore.
He hasn’t? From what I know he’s been travelling around the world/being an announcer/other random stuff this past year. He was even rumored to be involved as a director in Steve Nash’s 2nd Division (?) Spanish team.

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
Has he officially retired though? I’m not so sure.
And TBH, there was no "right" way to do it. The right way is to sit next to the player and ask him to move on , since you cant promise him a starting spot (which ADP wanted). I’m guessing A) Agnelli tried and failed to convince ADP to leave on his own accord or B) Agnelli didnt have the balls to do it and thought he would do it indirectly via a presser.
If A, he did it the right way and failed and then went to B. If B, then its understandable since it was Conte’s first season as a manager and he probably felt awkward,and even Agnelli was in only his 2nd full season. We dont really know all there is to it, the sequence of events.

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
I’m not quite sure that I agree with your assessment in part A.
Del Piero Form in his last 2 seasons
In his last two seasons in which he scored 8 and 9 goals, Juve was in its shittiest form ever; consecutive 7th finishes with the worst coaches ever (Ferrara, Zaccaroni, Del Neri). So 8-9 goals isn’t that bad considering that ADP was Juve’s top scorer. In the following two seasons, our top scorers (Matri/Vucinic) only managed to score 10 goals
Sitting on the bench
I don’t think Del Piero objected (or would have objected) to sitting on the bench. In Capello era, Del Piero was a lot younger and therefore had grounds to request not to be bench. 2012 is different from 2005
I still think that Del Piero could have stayed for 1-2 additional seasons with Juve, but Conte/Angelli had different opinions. The manner in which Del Piero parted with Juventus is Angelli’s biggest mistake with Juventus

I for one was glad to know, he is my idol, the reason I got into soccer and I am glad to given the opportunity to enjoy each of his appearance in the last season. Idk if conte had a hand in ADP leaving but I knew he wouldn’t accept bench just like pirlo didn’t, I also won’t speculate tht as soon as conte left ADP and agnelli patched up and he was involved in one of the juve legends game or something like tht. Dybala is practising his right foot. The quoted words was that "Allegri crosses the ball and I shoot with my right foot. But for now it’s more broken windows than goals."
Amazing if true. For a top professional footballer to try and improve something so basic is mind-blowing. With the right guidance (which I’m sure he gets at Juventus), the sky’s truly the limit for this kid.
And I also want to say that his first touch has improved so much since he joined. I initially thought that it was due to his improved physique, that he can control with better consistency (less fatigue in his muscles during games), but reading this, I can imagine it’s because he’s focused in improving that aspect as well.

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
We will not sell Morata, unless Morata himself requests for the move.
I might be wrong, but IIRC the buyback option is structured in a way that if Juve accepts any offer from any other clubs aside from Real in an amount that is higher than Real’s buyback option, then the excess would mostly go to Real’s pocket. It’s logical, because otherwise Real’s buyback option would not have any meaning if Morata’s market price goes up.
In this sense, there is absolutely no economic benefit for Juve to sell Morata, even if the offer is astronomical.
Of course, there is a possibility that Juve negotiate with Real to split the "profit", but it would be a hell of a complicated deal to do in such a short time, and I still can’t see why would Real let go of such advantage in terms of bargaininh power with Juve.
Ergo, I don’t think Morata is going anywhere this window.

Paolo – Just read this and thought to provide an update. My inquiries with the CDC and local health officials are ongoing. I have yet to locate an epistemology center with an international database. I would have thought that in the "information age" this would be facile and a given. Perhaps I am not asking the right people – hopefully the inquires will bear fruit.
Most importantly – how are you doing? Any progress on the treatment? Have the symptoms subsided?

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
Yes all my endeavors are proving much more difficult than I expected too.
Still waiting on a response from Brazil at my end.
Unfortunately not much has changed – still feeling remarkably unwell although there has been a bit of improvement in the last couple of weeks.
My father has managed to locate a supposedly good parasitologist here in Sydney who I will hopefully be able to see soon for an opinion.
Otherwise still searching for answers…
Thanks again for your help.

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
Fellow Bwrao brothers. I’ve been following this beautiful blog as a silent reader for some time now. It’s my first concrete comment and I just want to say that I love it over here. This site has become number one in my "most visited tabs" on my chrome home page. And a daily morning ritual before I start work. Frankly usually I would enjoy the beautifully written articles and heart warming/ sarcastically funny comments you guys come up with, but when it comes to gigi, I simply can’t stay silent.
I’ve been following Juventus since 2001 and i’m a die-hard serie A and azzuri fan. I’m from Lebanon and I would like to inform you that Juventus has one hell of a fan base in the Arab world. But when I go into the inevitable debate with football fans that fell for the young glamour of the other top leagues, I always feel that their love for football is a young teenage love that doesn’t understand the depth of feelings one might have for the sport. That’s why I love serie A. That’s why I will always love it first and foremost. It has something more, something deeper. The stars of serie A are not the "lady Gaga" and "Justin beiber" of the industry. They don’t control the hype of the media and everything commercial within. They are the beethovens and Mozarts of the industry. They have lesser likes on YouTube but everyone knows their class and elegance is beyond any class. Their loyalty and passion is beyond the materialistic world. Players like Ganluigi Buffon, Alex Del Piero, Paulo Maldini and even Francesco Totti. These players are the heart of Italian football. Something other fans may never understand.
When Buffon retires football will never be the same for me.
Sorry for the long post. I’m lost in my own thoughts.

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
Huh? Inter has never even bid once for Saponara, and they don’t seem awfully interested in him now either.
MLG please do not take this personally because it’s definitely not just you that does this but I need to rant real quick.
I really dislike statements like this. I really believe that the majority of media bullshit that they spew out is purely speculation and who might be a good fit for a good price for a team. I really think there’s absolutely no way of knowing if a team is interested or has made a bid for a player unless:
1. An agent said specifically that that team is or isn’t interested
2. The team themselves have gone on record saying they are interested or not interested in the player
3. The player has said they are or aren’t interested or there is or isn’t interest.
I understand the media might have some leads. But there’s really no way to know that a team isn’t looking to sign them ever, or that a team is super interested and ready to break the bank and sign someone.
This is why I can’t stand soccer "transfer reporting". It sucks. Unless there’s a lot of beef behind something, I urge you not to listen because there’s just really no way of knowing what’s going on behind the scenes.
/EndRant

Comment Body:
I’m presuming hating Russia is a Ukrainian thing?
Ps I’m planning to go to Kiev and Odessa in the summer. What do you think? Any suggestions?

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
Hating oppression, famine, destroying one’s people, culture, traditions, language, you name it, for so many years and current military invasion, annexation of Crimea, ongoing war with thousands dead, thousands injured, thousands displaced being a Ukrainian thing? I believe it is anyone’s thing, but definitely personal for me, yes.
I was born and raised in Ukraine and it is a beautiful country, I don’t know if now it is a good time to experience it. If you do travel to Ukraine, I would recommend to spend some time in the western part- Chernivtsi, Lviv, Carpathian mountains. Kyiv has over 1200 years of history, architecture, culture and would need about a week to just see the highlights. How much time do you have? Will you be staying on your own or have friends that live there?

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
I’m against all those things although I try not to paint a whole country with the same brushstroke if you know what I mean.
I do very much feel for the Ukrainian people.
I might go for about two or more months…
But I wanted to just pick say two places and not move around too much.
I have friends in Kyiv but not elsewhere.
Plus I wanted to go somewhere near the beach/sea at some point since its summer. That’s why I chose Odessa. Are there better places I should think of than Odessa for that?
Thanks for the tips re the west – I had heard Lviv is a cool city

Article Title: Juventus goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon to retire after 2018 World Cup in Russia
Comment Body:
Thank you. It is really a shame what is happening and I get very upset thinking about the whole situation. Still I strongly believe that Russia should have never be allowed to host the World Cup, they were able to get it due to bribes and total corruption, but it is another story. I still have family living in Russia and trust me, I know first hand how awful it really is.
I am planning on visiting my parents and extended family this summer as well, don’t have exact dates yet, they are mostly located in the west. Since you are planning on staying for a while, I would suggest Kyiv-Odessa-Lviv itinerary with venturing out into respective areas. Chernivtsi is called Ukrainian Paris, most beautiful University and grounds, definitely is worth a short trip. Unfortunately, due to ongoing war, local flights are limited, trains/busses might be a better choice. Since the economy is very weak, a dollar goes a long way, you will find transportation and accommodations affordable.
I’ve been to Odessa several times, interesting city and a melting pot for many cultures, as any port city would be. Offers anything from fancy hotels to modest hostels, too noisy for me and I live in NY Better, cleaner and less expensive beaches will be found a bit away from Odessa itself, I would have to look it up.
Definitely visit Lviv, Kamianets-Podilskyi Castle,Ivano-Frankivsk (my home town) and spend a few days up in the mountains. Local hutzul culture including but not limited to famous Easter eggs, folk music, wood crafts, etc. is located in Kosiv, Yaremche and surrounding areas. Beautiful.
I can talk about it for days If you’d like we can connect via skype or something and discuss more.

Article Title: Juventus manager Max Allegri: We must do even better to catch Napoli
Juventus manager Max Allegri: We must do even better to catch Napoli
Comment Body: This run of form is essential if we are going to knock Bayern out of the Champions League. The 11 win streak is extraordinary and we must keep it going, both in Serie A and in the coppa. A strong showing Wednesday is essential, because it is followed by three relatively easy games against teams in the lower half of the table. These are the games we need to thrive in, and continue to build confidence. Smashing Chievo, Genoa and Frosinone will have us enter the Napoli game oozing with confidence, and who knows, with Napoli playing Lazio in that span they may even drop some points. Beating Napoli on our turf will then set us atop the standings, and really make us a force to be reckoned with come time for Bayern to visit a few weeks later. Ideally, Morata also needs to figure it out in that span, because he is simply too clutch in the CL to not be used. Here’s to continuing this excellent run, cheers fellas.

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Nainggolan, the entire time he played for Cagliari, wanted to be a Juve player. We ended up getting distracted with the ill-fated Vucinic-Guarin swap and Roma swooped under our noses for Radja. Now, he’s keen to make-believe that he was a Romanista all along and tries to wind up Juventini whenever he gets a chance. I used to think this was a clever tactic but, over time, I’ve realized that he’s probably just really stupid. Some people are like that; you think they’re of average intelligence but, sooner or later, it dawns on you that they can’t stop saying moronic shit so they’re probably ultra-low IQ imbeciles.
All the best to you Radja, you’re a special, special boy!

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Good performance overall. Although we can still do a lot better. 1-0 could’ve been more, or arrived earlier, and been less dependant on another bit of magic by Paul&Paulo. The key to breaking up a defence (bus) like today’s, is a bigger variety of tempo, turning up the pace before calming down and doing it again irregularly . Coupled with side shifts done higher up the pitch, faster, rather than done by BBC. I’m sure the Allegri and the guys are working on it though, as today was another step in the right direction.
That said, I’m absolutely delighted with the win. The whole team were up to the task. A complete machine, with shiny parts in the right places; Dybala levelling up on his trequartista-quest, scoring a beauty, and on several occasions proving his first touch doubters wrong, while Pogba and Khedira were solid again, as usual these days. And Marchisio. Man of the match, playing his best game of the season so far. Claudio is the sun of our black and white photosynthesis.
My favourite part of the game was our recapturing of the ball, like rabid raccoons, as soon as we lost it in the first half. That, and the zoom-ins on Totti’s face.

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body: Pereyra in the hold behind the strikers was tailor made for the way Roma set themselves up today. Of course, if Pereyra was there and we were playing the 4-3-1-2 Spalletti would probably have tried to mirror that formation as well.

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body: lol completely agree with your last paragraph

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Coupled with side shifts done higher up the pitch, faster, rather than done by BBC.
In one sentence you’ve captured my whole problem with the 3-5-2. It’s not that I don’t think we play it well and, when using it, we’re still the best team in Serie A; it’s just that it’s painful to see Chiellini and Barzagli spend so much time with the ball on offense. With Roma parking the bus for 90’, there were so many times today we would have benefited from another offensive option.

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Zizou is my fav player ever, and I think a true playmaker type of player like him and Rui Costa is getting extinct, which is a shame. Ozil is probably the last of his kind, a pure creator that doesn’t contribute much anywhere else. The new generations of playmaker are usually a hybrid type, either they also have to contribute defensively or in scoring goals as well. I think nowadays, playmakers are more associated to the regista type ala Verratti, or the creative speedy inverted wingers like Hazard and Ribery.
Such a shame. Back in the day we had Zizou, Rui Costa, Riquelme, Valeron…

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body: I know we all are talking about this every 10 minutes, but I am still shocked at how good Dybala is. I expected a raw kid with a lot of potential when we signed him, not this beast. There was a moment in the game we he killed a 40 yard pass (was offside) and just continued in his stride where I just melted.

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body: Word, what really surprised me was the way he found the space in the hole while drifting time after time, mainly from the right. Great football instincts. Made a few slide ruler through balls from deep positions also. Dybala had a great game.

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Dybala’s first touch was excellent this game. He really is looking good.
Cuadrado was much better when he came on this time. He played within the system and kept the ball moving.
Chiellini was outstanding. Man he’s a good defender.
Khedira too was very good. He’s looking sharper n sharper and his injuries seem to be at bay so this is great news.
For the shirt time Morata was on again he seemed to persist with this conundrum of drifting left. I just don’t get it.
But that was an excellent win and being on Inter.

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body: Heavy period of games coming up so we’ve gotta get through fresh for Bayern – I hope he does some rotating v Inter midweek. I wouldn’t mind to see Marchisio get some rest even if that means we start Hernanes. I’d like to see Boner or Chiellini get a break too if that’s feasible.

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
"To tell the truth, I did not know there were people of Barcelona in the stands," Dybala said in quotes reported by Sport.

"It makes me happy that things are going well for me and the team and we are going to show that we are able to give more in the future."

Dybala has three caps for his country, although he is yet to feature alongside superstar Messi.

When asked by reporters if he would like to come up against his compatriot, Dybala replied: "No, I have a desire to play with Messi."

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Roma 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
These days players are so well media-trained that you just can’t spend too much time worrying about what they’re saying. Their statements are intended to do only two things: 1) avoid controversy; and 2) create a sense that they might leave so as to improve their hand at a future bargaining table.
They respond to questions as if on auto-pilot; some examples:
Q: Do you want to play for [insert oil-rich club name here]?
A: I’m happy at [insert current club]. In the future we’ll see but for now I’m only focused on our game against [insert next opponent].
Q: Would you like to play with [insert established elite player name here]?
A: I most certainly would like to play with him.
Q: You’ve won 10 games in a row and your next opponent comes into the upcoming game in poor form. Gonna be a really easy one, no?
A: Form aside, we both have strong history and we have to concentrate hard for 90’ to get the win. There is no such thing as an easy game in [insert league here].

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body:
Light snow falling and sparkling is pretty, skiing is fun. Sitting by the fireplace with a drink/book/lover is very nice.
Blizzard for 12-24 hours, with 2.5-3 feet snow afterwards that you have to clean in order to dig your car out and be able to walk on the sidewalk, travel ban except emergency vehicles, no public transportation, closed airports, canceled events/schools/games – not so much. So as always, it depends how you look at it.

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body: Living in DC, it’s not that bad because things actually close down if it snows badly enough. I’m from Cleveland though, and back home life goes on despite these conditions. Anywhere with Lake Effect Snow gets this kind of buildup pretty regularly, and dealing with it sucks.

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body:
Very promising start to the half, but its been very meh, although solid since. We’re getting into great positions, but the last touch has been lacking throughout. I really wish we had played Evra midweek, and Sandro today. Mandzukic bas been criminally starved of service in the box.
This Roma team looks ripe for the picking, like Inter earlier in the season. I think one goal is all thats needed go open the floodgates. I really hope we score soon.

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body: Good half, we had a few chances but couldn’t score. Maybe some changed might help late on the half. Marchisio and Chellini are performing like it’s the World Cup’s final! Great performances. Dybala and Pogba doing their jobs extremely well too.

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body:
We have been in complete control, but didn’t manage to get really dangerous (except Dybala but was offside). This is particularly bad if we consider that Roma has been doing a shitty job at marking our playmakers – Marchisio and Dybala have been mostly free so far. We are probably too defensive with Evra and Licht, so I expect that we could see Sandro or Cuadrado in the second half.
They were really scared in the first 20-25 minutes, if only we had scored we would have destroyed them.
Anyway, as predicted, not an easy game. We need one goal quickly, and then possibly another.

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body:
Khedira is having himself a game and a half, his link up with Dybala is wonderful to watch.
Dybala has been all over the pitch.
Chiellini is an absolute stud in defence, love his game.
Starting both Lichsteiner and Evra is far too defensive, this game needs Sandro.

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body: Who should start against Bayern, Evra or Sandro? Evra’s experience will be important for us as he’s played against Bayern before and even scored against them, but Sandro is much more helpful on the counter and harder to defend against

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body:
Dybala decrees that we get the three points, and we get the three points. Most decisive player in Serie A.
This game was a lot like the Milan game, except in the end when Roma pushed us – they’re still a quality team, despite their current troubles.
Never more Evra and Lichtsteiner together (unless we’re like 3-0 and need to defend the result).
A tricky game and a very important result. On we go!

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Roma
Comment Body:
A very ‘Italian’ game, 3-5-2 vs 3-5-2
Loved seeing Juve press 1T, and play quick combinations. Very tactical, almost chess-like approach. I love matches like this.
Favorite moment was Pogba’s ridiculous touch/backheel to Evra who in turn knocked the wind out of Szcezny

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:
Sorry to start this with an off tooic but is anyone watching the Empoli vs Milan?
Saponara’s vision is excellent, and Donnaruma showed his inexperience on the tying goal. Is a good match so far.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:
Saponara is the number 10 Juve wants/needs. Italian/ familiar with the Serie A, tactical intelligence and exceptional technique and vision..
However, Watching Milan last round and right now today, it just makes it all obvious why Juve wins so many banana-skin games. like one of my most favourite players, Alessio, said "You can see it in how they defend: 10 players behind the ball like a Lega Pro side trying to avoid relegation. This is the secret – this is what makes the difference."
Milan Played a perfect game against Fiorentina last week, sound defensively, and alert for the whole of the game with great tactical awareness. Whereas today, immediately after going ahead, they dropped intensity and you could see they had become lazy. Taking the lead for granted and perhaps underestimating a hard-working opponent.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body: Thats is my though on Saponara as well. Milan need to much mental strenght to upkeep their hopes for european competition. They do drop energy if they are up on the score line. Mila has so much work to do, both on the squad and himself.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body: Saponara’s immense quality is obvious, he could be one of the best attacking mids in the world if given the chance at a big club like Juventus. He won’t even be too expensive considering how talented he is, get him!

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:
He looks good… at Empoli. Juventus is a different matter altogether. He would be a bet – not to say that I’m against it, just saying that he cannot be the TQ we finally buy for Allegri to build the team on. We need someone more proven than Saponara – then Saponara can be a quality reserve and gain experience in a big team, perhaps be ready in 1 or 2 years.
Also, it would be hard to accommodate both Berardi and Saponara coming in in the same transfer window. Both are young and unproven. Berardi would require a transition towards a 4-3-3, Saponara is better for the 4-3-1-2. We’ll see.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:
Was Dybala proven?
I think Saponara would be able play as cm in 4-3-3

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:
No, he wasn’t. He had better numbers than Saponara, but obviously not proven in a higher-level team. That’s why we also brought in Mandzukic – experienced, international profile, proven at the highest levels. Now, what happened was that Dybala exploded immediately and became even more decisive than Manzo (who also had physical troubles at the beginning of the season), but the society has clearly planned the market knowing perfectly well that Dybala was a bet. In the same way, if we bring in Saponara, in my opinion we should also provide Allegri with another TQ that we can safely rely on for all the time Saponara needs to adapt to the new environment. I can’t see us going into CL with Saponara right away (and again, this year we had Morata and Mandzukic as starters in CL for the very first game).
On a different note, I like Bonaventura a lot. Probably not what be need, but a very interesting player.

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:

But I agree with you, alongside Berardi and Saponara, it would be amazing if they got a proven TQ. Not sure if we can afford all three though

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:
Buffon; Barzagli, Bonucci, Chiellini; Cuadrado, Khedira, Marchisio, Pogba, Evra; Dybala, Mandzukic
Szczesny; Manolas, De Rossi, Rudiger; Florenzi, Pjanic, Keita, Digne; Nainggolan, Salah; Dzeko
I like the fact that Cuadrado will start. With Evra most likely starting on the left flank, Cuadrado would provide a needed attacking spark on the other flank. Lichtsteiner-Evra would be too defensive
On the other hand, Roma are expected to line up in a 3-5-2 for the first time. Florenzi will most likely having a more offensive role on the right flank and Nainggolan will play Vidal’s role in a box-to-box role
It should be an exciting match to watch. We always score lots of goals against Roma. I can’t remember the last time we lost points against Roma in Turin. I expect us to win by a big margin

Comment Body:
That was amazing. I had seen cross-country in Central Park – but NOT in a blizzard.
Talking NY – Do NY Juventni get together to watch the Juve games? Last year a friend took me a Real pub in Brooklyn. I was forewarned not to mention I am NOT a Real fan. I accepted the challenge and went with Bianconeri (ADP’s) home jersey. I was reminded more than a few times of the standing ovation at the Bernabeu.
I have been at the Football Factory when in town. IIRC dweb once said it is not always his preferred spot. A couple years ago I met some folks at the Football Factory from Juve’s NY fan club – although the information they had was scant. Has that changed with more activities and get togethers? If not the Football Factory, any alternatives and suggestions for celebrating Juve with fellow NY Juventini would be appreciated.
Posting pics – perhaps this has been suggested.

Comment Body:
Thank you! I will have a look, never had an issue posting pics before, weird.
When I lived in East Village I used to frequent local venues, even though my friends were anything but Juventus fans, made it difficult at times to enjoy the game, never went to the Football Factory as far as I know. Several Irish pubs in Midtown I liked and one Uptown (Doctor Watson’s I believe) that had a nice crowd for CL games. Oh those good old days.
Now I mostly watch at home, often host a nice party for big CL games, world cup,etc. with friends coming over. Last summer had a fun 4th July pool party during Copa America final with my 6 year old godson and his cousins (and most of their dads) all wearing Messi’s jerseys, therefore had to sit on the floor and only get cake if could name a Chilean player. Yes, I did that to little kids

Comment Title: Always wondering what snow feels like
Comment Body:
When I went to Japan, I thought it was snowing, apparently the guy next to me told me that it was a gale.
What’s the difference? Gale, snow, blizzard?

Article Title: Juventus vs. Roma match preview: Time, TV schedule, and how to watch the Serie A
Comment Body:
Gale, I thought, simply refers to heavy wind.

Article Title: Report: AC Milan offer up Mattia De Sciglio-Martin Cáceres swap deal to Juventus
Comment Body:
No offence, but this is a no brainer. I love Caceres (and you guys know it!), but we’re not short on central defenders, we’re short on right fullbacks. Also this deal is extremely intelligent because Milan actually have two right backs (Abate and Calabria) and they lack a quality defender alongside Romagnoli.
RB/RWB: Licht, De Scilgio, Cuadrado, Padoin
CB: Bonucci, Chellini, Barzagli, Rugani
LB/LWB: Sandro, Evra, Asamoah, Padoin
Midfielders: Marchisio, Pogba, Khedira, Hernanes, Pereyra, Sturaro, Lemina, Asamoah, Padoin
TQs: Pereyra, occasionally Dybala and Pogba.
Forwards: Zaza, Mandzukic, Morata, Dybala
That’s a squad with extreme quality depth (except at the TQ position), possible formations are 3-5-2 and 4-3-1-2.

Comment Body:
3 man defence formations and 4 man defence formations need different type of players, in a 3 man formation you only need strikers, fullbacks, midfielders and defenders. In a 4 man formation you need TQs and wingers more.. I think it’s hard to find the correct personnel/squad for these TWO formations together, we gotta choose one. Either 4 man or 3 man.
For example, 5 CBs for a 3 man backline seems perfect, but it’s a bit too much for a 4 man backline formation. Wingers and TQs have absolutely no use in a 3-5-2 formation, on the other hand they’re one of the most important players in a 4 man backline.. you get the point.
(Btw, I’m only comparing formations that our team has used before, such as 3-5-2, 4-3-3 and 4-3-1-2. Of course there are other 3 man backline formations that involve wingers and TQs, but we simply do not use it).

Article Title: Report: AC Milan offer up Mattia De Sciglio-Martin Cáceres swap deal to Juventus
Comment Title: Winter mercato is meant to "tweak" not to overhaul
Comment Body:
As successful 3-5-2 has been in Serie A – it has failed us in Europe. This is even true against the so-called mediocre and lower-level teams, let alone the top-tier teams and their fast wingers. Even Conte shifted to a back-4 when facing Real couple years ago. Earlier this year Max brought out Zona Mista in the home game to widen the field. This requirement (wider defense) will not change with (or without) the De Sciglio or Cáceres.
I fully appreciate and understand that "replacing" Cáceres with a FB (even as a back-up) is problematic, especially given how thin (and aging) we are with CBs on the roster. Additionally in the discussion about the back-line (3 vs. 4, starters/reserves and permutations) we need to also include Rugani – his role and development.
He is adjusting and acclimating to a 3 back system. It is a work-in-progress and it is more than obvious that he is "uncomfortable". He is caught out of position up-field (tracking primarily) and in the box and hesitant in his approach up-field. He has trouble managing the width and connecting with the midfield and attack. This is not to question his talent and attitude and perhaps this "swap" would be an opportunity to transition to a 4-back system which he has excelled at and will be an easier one than the challenges he has been facing with a 3-back system.
However it is too late in the season to unwind all of the training and transition into a fundamentally different base-formation. Cáceres’ versatility to transition between Italy and Europe is very important and it would be detrimental to loose that even if it would mean not bringing in De Sciglio – whom under Max and Gigi’s Juve will find his groove.
The issue is not just reserves but this "swap" will translate into an overhaul (not a tweak/adjustment) and will impact Rugani’s development and with these Juve’s campaigns in both Italy and Europe. We have already seen earlier in the season the deleterious impact when the team (personnel and formation) is in a state of flux. Although the addition of De Sciglio would have been near-perfect in the summer, it too late to change now in mid-season.
In short perhaps it is time to move Cáceres and bring in De Sciglio – but not in January.

The top eight teams from Serie A are seeded randomly in a drawing in July. Home field is determined by seeding; the Italian wikipedia page breaks it down, here’s an English translation.
They’re professionals doing a job, their personal affections aren’t terrible relevant.
I’m not sure if this is a good question or completely inane. But I don’t know the answer, lol.

Article Title: Report: AC Milan offer up Mattia De Sciglio-Martin Cáceres swap deal to Juventus
Comment Body:
Welcome Khodor!
I’ll try to answer some of your questions…
1. Coppa Italia home and away is decided as follows:
a. Rnd 16 the home teams are the top 8 serie A teams from the previous years position in Serie A. They enter the competition at this point.
b The home team in the Quarter Finals is the higher ranked team (except that the top 8 serie A teams are not ranked by Serie A league position but rather by the drawing of lots – so Lazio drew a higher lot than Juventus).
c. Who plays at home first in the Semi-finals either follows the same rule in (b) above or the first home team is the first team listed in the fixture sheet from the way the draw is set up.
2. Good observation. I know I would always want to play for my beloved club but I guess professionalism and opportunities play a part and Juve is best in Italy so why wouldn’t you want that chance!
3. Very good points. I agree with you it should be 90mins if it’s not cos as you say any first or second half overtime is in theory time wasted.
4. Referees association, club officials and calcio officials spoke to each other often behind the scenes. It was alleged that this was done to fix matches. Particularly Juve was targeted. Juve was found guilty and punished with demotion to Serie B. Other clubs like Inter were let off.
Last year, more trials and appeals ended up not proving that Juve fixed any matches or influenced the Serie A standings but did show that Juve and many other clubs officials did often talk to and treat referree officials well.
In light of that it seems Juve was wrongly stripped of titles and demoted to Serie B and other clubs like Inter benefitted by being let off.

Article Title: Report: AC Milan offer up Mattia De Sciglio-Martin Cáceres swap deal to Juventus
Comment Body:
A slight correction, Paolo, re: calciopoli.
It was alleged that this was done to fix matches. Particularly Juve was targeted. Juve was found guilty and punished with demotion to Serie B
Juventus was cleared of all match fixing allegations at the time. Their punishment was for improper contact with a referee designator. Basically, Moggi’s relationship with the head referee was determined to be suspect and, though without any evidence of definite wrongdoing, Juventus was punished for essentially creating a situation in which inappropriate and illegal activity COULD happen. Very weak charge, imo, especially considering the insanely heavy sentence.

Article Title: Report: AC Milan offer up Mattia De Sciglio-Martin Cáceres swap deal to Juventus
Comment Body:
I’ll add a few things. I don’t know elsewhere, but in Italy there are three "gradi di giudizio" (I don’t know how to exactly translate it, it means that a trial can be repeated up to three times if there’s an appeal). The first trial was conducted very quickly in 2006, to the point that many people protested that the civil rights of the accused were being denied due to this improper speed. Still, there was a raging sentiment against Juventus those days (imagine that Calciopoli was the wet dream of millions of supporters of other teams that could justify why their teams sucked so much, "because Juve cheats"), and something very akin to a witch hunt took place. So the first trial was closed and Juventus as a society was found guilty and sent to Serie B. Key Juventus managers like Moggi and Giraudo were convicted as well, along with around 40 referees and linesmen. We were stripped of 2 scudettis, and so on.
Then the second trial came. Around 95% of the referees that were found guilty during the first trial were acquitted of all charges. This practically destroyed the core element of the first trial: that Moggi had created a web of referees under his control that could help Juventus during key matches. This can all be found in the official papers of the trial – they’re in italian, obviously. Anyway, one would have expected that, with so many people acquitted, the whole accusation would fall. It did not happen. Moggi was found guilty, again, even though he practically had no accomplices (in the end, after the third trial, only one referee was found guilty, practically a scapegoat). Italian judges protect each other, usually, and they did so this time: they could not completely thrash the work done by their colleagues in the first trial. Also, Juventus would have had a sound basis from which to get a payback of more than 400 millions from FIGC, and that was something that no one wanted (except, obviously, us).
The third trial more or less went as the second, with a couple more referees acquitted and a confirmation of the conviction for Moggi.
Now, this is my point of view, and it’s a very strong point of view, but a few facts remain:
- only one referee was found guilty at the end of the whole process (from an initial number of around 40)
- it was proven that the appointment of the referees for the games was not under the control of Moggi (meaning, he could not choose which referee would be assigned to each game – this was also in the charges from the first trial)
- a total number of 5 games was considered "fixed", only 2 of these involved Juventus. The referee and all the linesmen for 1 of these 5 matches were acquitted of all charges, leaving doubts on even the capacity of logical thinking by the judges (how could Moggi manipulate the result if all the referees were clean? psychic powers?)
- the phone calls between Inter managers and the referees were ignored and never again considered in the process
So, lots of irregularities and strange decisions. It pains me to say this since I’m Italian, but our justice system sucks, and sucks hard. Especially when powerful people are involved. But that’s how things are.

Article Title: Report: AC Milan offer up Mattia De Sciglio-Martin Cáceres swap deal to Juventus
Comment Body:
FM wise, I would be inclined to accept this deal. However, in real life and in January, I’m not sure. Long term impact should be positive, but short term impact could be detrimental due to lack of CB cover (particularly Chiellini’s cover.
In any case, I highly doubt Milan, even as stupid as their recent transfers have been, would do this.

Article Title: Report: AC Milan offer up Mattia De Sciglio-Martin Cáceres swap deal to Juventus
Comment Body:
Why would this be stupid for them, though?
They have two right fullbacks (Abate and Calabria), and they lack a quality CB next to Romagnoli. I think this deal is an absolute win-win for both teams.

Article Title: Report: AC Milan offer up Mattia De Sciglio-Martin Cáceres swap deal to Juventus
Comment Body:
Of course they need Caceres. I reckon all Serie A team not called Juventus need Caceres. But to say that Milan offered De Sciglio for Caceres is far fetched, IMO.
If they’re desperate to land Caceres, they’ll try to buy him outright. Regarding their RB situation, I’m not up to speed with their team, so I can’t say I know for sure, but De Sciglio can also play LB, and Abate is not getting any younger.
Setting that aside for a moment, I was impressed by MDS during his debut season, but it’s been awhile since the last time I saw him playing well.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body:
Everyone (including a Roma fan I was talking to at my workplace) seems to think Roma is headed towards certain destruction. It’s true we’re clear favorites, but I’d like the team to stay focused because it’s going to be a tricky game. Roma is an unstable and unpredictable team, and while this often means they’ll deliver shitty performance when you expect them to win, it might also mean that they’ll give 120% and manage to snatch a win you didn’t expect (or maybe a draw, like with Barcellona). They’re desperate and will probably fight like animals – a win on sunday might win their fans back and even reopen their race towards a CL spot.
So, better not underestimate them, beware their fast counterattacks and kill them quickly and safely working on their relatively weak defense.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body: I think if we get the first goal, they lack the toughness to fight back. They might crumble badly. I’m hoping for ruthlessness.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body:
I watched the Hellas Verona match….I want those 90 minutes back. Hitting the woodwork aside, Roma simply isn’t a very good team, and they continue to fall to pieces at the first sign of adversity.
I think they will get one, Pjanic free kick or PK, but this has 3-1 Juve written all over it.
Regarding the CdT mentioning of Carletto above, I do think once the Stadio della Roma is complete, they will be able to lure a top manager but not until then. A brand new 60,000 set stadium will help that club in a big way.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body: Yes, from a management perspective, there are only two Italian clubs poised to excel: us and Roma. There are other well-run clubs such as Udinese, Sassuolo and Atalanta but they don’t have the fan-base to truly take a step up. Inter will be an interesting club to follow over the next few years in terms of whether they can get their shit together; I’d give them 50/50 odds based on what I’ve seen to date under Thohir. Milan, sadly, will have to hope for an abundance of good luck to re-establish themselves as a force; if ever there was a club in need of a thorough housecleaning, it’s them.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body: While I can’t stand the guy, De Laurentiis has done a bang up job with Napoli since he took over. Of course, they don’t have the new stadium planned like Roma do, but their performances have been largely consistent with impressive revenues, at least for Italy.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body:
Inter is on a tight spot right now. They might resurrect… or they risk to fall hard. They’re full of debts and desperately need to make it back into CL next year. Napoli’s situation is definitely better right now, but they lack history (except for the years of Maradona, but is not much and is many years ago) and their fanbase is smaller.
Roma might become an interesting project, but they need the stadium and a different mentality. Both of them will take years to obtain.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body: What about Napoli? They have the squad and manager, but they definitely need to fix their inner problems such as income, stadiums, management, fans, etc.

Comment Body: Was sitting on a couch with my dad (doesnt care a toss for calcio), my sister (idem) and my younger brother (unrepentant and woeful Romanista). He was chirping all game to my sister about how sharp Roma is and how they deserve to win, how the refs always have it out for Roma and favor Juve, how she should root for Roma if she is to ever watch Serie A. When Bonucci slammed that loose ball, he threw the stack of magazines that were next to him in the air and aggressively stormed out of the room – all i could do was grin my most satisfied grin possible.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body:
Speaking with Corriere dello Sport, Juve legend Tacchinardi said:
Juventus has once again become a steamroller. Maybe they ate something bad at the start of the season, but now it seems to me that Juve is hungrier than normal. Once again it seems to me like Conte’s Juve – sly, frenetic, and very physical, with blood in her eyes. To start the season, perhaps things were taken for granted and you pay for that. But the player’s pride kicked in, as it happens when things don’t go well, and there was a reaction. The secret is with the society: at Juve, there is a constant hunger for victory in the atmosphere.

Against Lazio, I saw an extraordinary viciousness: you need only look as far as Zaza’s performance. Champions? When I saw the draw, I thought 60% BM, 40% Juve but it seems to me that in the last month Juve has raised the bar and can play without fear, all things are even. Today, Allegri’s squad seems stronger mentally than last year and is tougher. You can see it in how they defend: 10 players behind the ball like a Lega Pro side trying to avoid relegation. This is the secret – this is what makes the difference.

Viciousness is the right word. If this level of grinta can be maintained for the balance of the season? Anything is possible.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body: Caceres is leaving in June for free, so why not. De Sciglio has taken a serious dip in form but the fact that he’s only 23, and the fact that he’s got a lot of experience already under his belt leads me to believe he could be worth the punt. He’s level-headed, and won’t crack up a Ferrari. Ability-wise I think he has a solid foundation on which to build upon, but then I think back to Berardi eating him alive. What concerns me is he seems to get down on himself, so if his head isn’t right then he may never recover. A move to Vinovo could be just what he needs, so he would be a project and need to earn his place. That could bring out the best in him.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Title: Here is the gem who has accomplished way more than the collection of perennial whiners they call Ass Roma.
Comment Body:
The funny part is that thread in which they have interviewed Danny( which shouldn’t have been pinned to our home page), the dude actually starts off with "Roma beat Juve convincingly 2-1 at the start of the season".. really? from what I recall, if it weren’t for the lucky save by the ever error-prone Arsenal loanee, Bonucci would have tied the game 2-2.. Not to mention a 10-man Juve despite obvious lack of form and chemistry had made Roma wet their pants for nearly 25 minutes at the end of the game..Has the word "convincingly" has gotten it’s meaning changed or they smoke something else amongst roma fans..
Just like Gigi said in his yesterday’s interview, let’s beat them and leave them 10 points behind us.
And For the sake of Serie A and everything Italian football, if these chokers never make it to UCL again, it will be too SOON. They are an embarrassment for the whole league in Europe… and their fanbase as delusional as the club itself, still thinking a 40-fucking-year-old dude is gonna play false 9 and save their season, because some bald fuck who once tried it a decade ago is gonna try it again. Sure.
Fuck Roma, Let’s bury them..
