Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Title: I want to share a story!!!
Comment Body:
The fire FGJ unwittingly rifled kinda relates.
I have an uncle who is a fan of football but not a specific team, back in the day to my annoyance he would cheer the team Juve where playing, we would always have friendly arguements and debates as to who was the best or who will rise and who will fall. I was the staunch Juve fan, my uncle was more of a neutral and my younger brother was a Milan fan, as you can imagine debates and arguement would be rife and the winner would be happy to have won such a debate. This specific event which i will delve into, happened exactly 10 years ago, Juve where playing Empoli on the day and where running away with the league, my bro always came with the arguement that Milan where better in Europe and we Domestic. On that specific day or year i should say we had a very strong team but neither my uncle or bro would admit it, we had won the previous league and where headed for another and to my surprise on that day me and my uncle sat down to watch the match and what he followed to say to me shocked me to my core as he had never been on either mine or my brothers side in our arguements, but my bro wasnt there, and he sed to me, "Zia, this team is full of champions, and this team will go down in history they will win everything." We had a defence consisting of Buffon, Zambrotta, Cannavaro, Thuram, a strong midfield of Emerson, Vieira, Camoranesi and Nedved and out strike force had Trezeguet, Ibrahimovic and of course ADP. I looked at him bemused as to what he just said, i asked him to repeat and he said it again. He followed that with, "Juve are a team built on morales and strong foundation, when one falls another will rise".
He continued to tell me about the past Juve teams of Scirea, Platini and Baggio eras and said when this team loses one icon it gains two and at the time i found it hard to believe due to the shock of having my uncle finally side with anyone let alone me. He also said that team was the start of something special, he had never seen a team full of so many winners and champions and said if treated correctly that team will dominate Europe let alone Italy for years and my faith was growing and growing. These words where spoken to me by my uncle who would support Empoli againt my Juve, or Inter against my Juve, it wasnt until years later he explained why he used to do that.
Obviously come May 2006 we lifted the scudetto again and it just happened my uncle was with me to watch that aswell and he looked and said it again that this team will go places. Mere weeks later the news of Farciopoli broke out and lo and behold our team had been ravaged and the the spine torn out of the skeleton. As you know i was devastated and heart broken as im sure we all where. We where being demoted to C1 and i thought, Juve is finished and what my uncle said next was even more unbelievable than what he said a few months before, he said "this isnt the last of the Old Lady, within 5 years she will claim her rightful throne at the top of Italy’s heirarchy". I wont lie and say i wasnt sceptical but as the hearings passed and reviews made and case finalised we ended up in serie B. Italy won the world cup, we where in serie B. I thought Juve was finished, player after player was leaving and it was only a matter of time till the legends left aswell. Then news broke out about ADP, Trez, Nedved, Camo and Buffon would stay to bring Juve back i had a glimmer of hope. My uncle left for Canada i started uni and life went on.
Two weeks ago my uncles returned for my wedding which is next week, he brought me a gift, it was the VCR recording of that very match vs Empoli which was 10 years ago today, he reminded me what he said all thos years ago and he was right, Juve are sitting pretty at the top of Italias echeleon withh everyone else drooling wanting to be like her. It was a few days ago he told me he was always a Juve fan and only told me now because he didnt want to choose between me and my bro, he didnt want to add friction, needless to say we both love him dearly, but i can only imagine if i had known what i know now back then how everything would be different.
We sat down brought out our old dusty VCR struggled to get the bloody thing hooked up and working and watched the match and it brought back soooooo many memories. All those arguements and debates. Looking back i truly do wish i knew he was a Juve fan, i mean who wouldnt want to know their crazy football mad uncle supports the same team as me, but i can understand why he never told me, me and my younger bros "sometimes" used to get violent and petty over Milan and Juve and i think it was better he was a "neutral".
Sorry if i bored you but yeh. Morale of the story, Juve wont fall down, if they do (and somehow it is orchestrated that they do fall) they will rise stronger than ever.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body:
Well, there is truth to the prevalence of Juve fans in Sicilia. When FIAT factories opened up in the North, many Sicilian men left their homes in the economically depressed south and headed north for jobs. Their families largely remained in the south and the father toiled away, hundreds of miles away from his family, sending whatever money home when he could. Logically, a lot of those men began to root for the team that was, essentially, paying their paychecks. That appreciation of a better life for their families afforded by the Agnelli family opened up an entire region, Sicilia, to becoming Juve fans.
Aside from VERY passionate support in the cities of Palermo and Catania – Juventus fans, more or less, dominate Sicily for this very reason even today.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body:
They were saying over at Roma blog that Juve fans are kids and Siciliani
No, THEY didn’t, only I made 1 post about it in reply to one of your loving members post saying Roma are ‘the laughing stock of Italian football’ and I didn’t say your fans are kids, I said:"You are considered a kids club in Italy".
So it was not an opinion, but a fact: In Italy Juve are considered a ‘kids club’ as many kids support Juve, the same as all teenagers walk around with Barca/Madrid shirts instead of a shirt from the club out of their own city. English would call it ‘bandwagoning’.
That is not bad in itself, it shows your exposure due to the succes you have and have had, so I can see that it is something that the club can be proud about.
I bet our owner loves this concept and is trying to get (international) exposure as well, getting 14 yr old kids from all over the place wearing Roma kids.
That is however not something Romans want to be associated with, as you are aware they are so proud (in an arrogant way even) of their city, that they don’t want bandwagon fans.
I have to tell you a story though that (no matter how freaking weird for me) was quite impressive: Last september I was in Modica Alta, at the highest point, quietly enjoying the marvelous view over the city with a bottle of wine and my wife.
It was the evening of Man City-Juventus and suddenly, on that peacefully quiet evening, the whole town underneath us exploded: I heard screaming, shouting, singing from one moment to another, as if the Etna had suddenly erupted….
You had scored the equalizer (2nd explosion came a couple minutes later).
I really don’t get it (I am from Haarlem, 20kms from AMsterdam, so I support MY HOMETOWN team (Haarlem), not some other team (Ajax, PSV, whatever) from another city), but I have to admit that it was pretty impressive experiencing that.
As you probably predicted: the next day was Roma-Barcelona, I was lucky to get a guy in a local bar to show the game on a small and old TV, I was watching alone with my wife and some drunk English fellow that happened to be there as well, no one else, (definately not the local Sicilians), cared.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body:
Regarding ‘bandwagon-ing’:
In part because it isn’t a regional club or one tied to a specific city (despite being older than Torino, they selected the name ‘Juventus’ and instead went with a less location-specific club name), in part bc of their industrialist owners being some of the first and longest standing industrial firms in Italy (well recognized brand and large employer of italians), and lastly in part bc of their specific contribution to the national team, Juventus has always drawn a more diverse and expansive fan base than any other Italian team.
The Italian diaspora also aided in this as italians without a particular city they identify with looked at the national team (that many rooted for) and saw numerous players at Juventus to root for. This is, for example, why you find a lot of Juventus fans in America, I think.
There’s a reason why our old lady is the Fidanzata d’Italia.

Article Title: Know your enemy: Talking Juventus-Roma with Chiesa Di Totti's head honcho
Comment Body:
Good Morning from under the snow:) Boy, we got tons of snow here and it is supposed to go on for another 24 hours, I suppose. I hope everyone in Northeast is safe and warm, and everywhere else in the world. Great weekend to stay in and enjoy some football.
Had too much coffee this morning, plenty of time to read current articles and every single comment, and despite my better judgement went to visit our Roma friends at the Totti’s church over there. Interesting place, I have to say. My hat off to Tre and a few others that tried to engage in a conversation, I did not dare to even say hello. Some seemed to be forever lost in 2006 and all that sadness. As much as I love a nice argument, I don’t care for name-calling and hate.
All we need is love (as the man once said). And Forza Juve!
I am very much looking forward tomorrow’s game. Roma might be playing 6-3-1 and try to get us on the counter. Juventus is much more physically prepared and we can go for full 90 minutes, pressure and skills. Juventus=grinta+ pressure+skills+wonderful Gigi smile these days. Here is to a convincing win, lads!

Article Title: Andrea Barzagli, Roberto Pereyra return to training ahead of Juventus' showdown with Roma
Comment Body:
"We were on our way back from Athens after we played a very bad match against Panathinaikos. It was 4 o’clock in the morning. At the airport there was a group of guys waiting for us who did not look peaceful. When Zidane went through, they made fun of him and pushed him. That was the end for them. Montero takes his glasses off, puts them down on the table, and then runs at them and kicks and punches them. Then Fonseca joined him.
Montero loved and respected Zizou, just like I loved and respected Montero. We need more players like him and it’s a shame. He was unique. To him Juventus wasn’t just a club he played for, it was like his family. I will never forget that moment."
- Carlo Ancelotti

Article Title: Andrea Barzagli, Roberto Pereyra return to training ahead of Juventus' showdown with Roma
Comment Title: The pink squares are goals, black squares are shots that didn't go in.
Comment Body: A lot of data goes into Caley’s xG figures. He’s got a list somewhere, but it factors in basically anything anyone could think of (and has a really good correlation with actual goals).

Article Title: Andrea Barzagli, Roberto Pereyra return to training ahead of Juventus' showdown with Roma
Comment Title: And the size of the squares?
Comment Body: At least tell me whether bigger xG numbers are better or worse, because I don’t even know what we’re trying to see here.

Article Title: Andrea Barzagli, Roberto Pereyra return to training ahead of Juventus' showdown with Roma
Comment Body:
xG are goals you’d expect to happen from the shots taken. The bigger the square, the higher the probability of the shot going in. So that big, pink square would be expected to go in a lot more than the smaller pink square just next to it given the factors of the shots. The information factors in a ton of variables (I really wish I had the list off hand – I know he’s tweeted it, but I don’t even remotely remember when), and seems to be pretty accurate.
Basically the data is just saying that Dybala is getting exactly the results you’d expect from him in terms of shots – which is a really good thing. On the other hand, it seems that Higuain is massively out-performing his expected production. Napoli are riding the wave while he’s hot, but one should expect him to cool off significantly before the end of the season.

For who missed it Juventus.com dedicted a whole section to J-Village construction
The’re also a video of the work in progress
I fear that watching constantly J-Village construction progress makes me a umarell

Umarell /uma’rɛl/ (oo-mah-rell), n; pl. Umarells. People, usually retired men, who spend time watching construction works, often holding their hands behind their back, occasionally commenting on what is going on, sometimes trying to tell the workers what to do. Umarell is a word that entered Italian slang from the Bolognese for "cute/odd little man".

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
Ahaha you should, not many people had faith in them including myself, I was Sturaro’s biggest critic but he has won me over because he just keeps improving with every match and he looks very capable of stepping into Khedira’s shoes should he pick up another injury.
Sturaro strikes me as the type of player who doesn’t have natural ability so would be a very average player at a mid table club but at Juve he’s surrounded by world class midfielders and is absorbing everything like a sponge which has taken him on a path to become a very high quality midfielder and just an overall beast in the middle of the pitch. He has also matured playing the peace maker on more than one occasion and leader instructing other players where to stand and who to pass the ball too, he was also seen hyping up the Juve fans. Very impressed.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
I’m hoping he can start to add some goals and assists to his game, he has the heart to be a mainstay in our team for a longtime.
I’m actually excited for a sturaro mandragora marchisio midfield some time in the future, been wanting more Italians in the team for a while

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
But Sturaro will always be an uttility player.
He reminds me a lot of Nocerino.
Never had the talent of Marchisio but could have been a very useful player for Juventus. Great workrate, intelligent positioning, does what the Mister wants him to do, decent enough passing en ball controle,…
Very glad to have him in our squad, though. That is the kind of bench-players I’m ok with. Instead of someone named Padoin.
Just don’t make more of him than he is.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Title: You say that Marchisio is talented
Comment Body: But I remember 5 years ago not many people would use the word "talented" to describe Claudio.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
Marchisio always had the talent to be one of the best midfielders in the world.
He just lacked dettermination. When the team didn’t play well Marchisio would disappear.
Conte gave him that dettermination and since then he uses his full potential.
I always believed in Marchisio’s talent. But when I see Sturaro I just see a decent footballer. Nothing more, nothing less.

Comment Body: Sturaro reminds me of the inelegant but effective Darren Fletcher at MU before he got sick in 2010. When Fletcher was red-carded in second leg of 2009 UCL semi-final and therefore ineligible for the final vs Barcelona, Jose Mourinho commented: "Fletcher is more important than people think. His work in midfield, especially in the midfield ‘wars’, in crucial matches is very important. Man United will miss his pace and aggression in defensive actions: he ‘eats’ opponents in defensive transition. I believe Xavi and Andrés Iniesta are happy Fletch is not playing." That describes the role we ask Sturaro to play. James Rodriguez sure would’ve been happy if Sturaro hadn’t played in last year’s UCL semifinal.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
Sturaro’s strong point is his energy, determination, and his grittiness. In these areas, no Juve midfielders can match him. Right about now, this is the whole point of having him in the squad, to give Allegri the option to play a midfielder whose role is to "bite" the opposition’s midfield, not to give them time to dilly dally on the ball. Incidentally, in a well drilled squad like Juve, having just one player who runs that much more would in some ways give energy to the others, push them to run just a little bit more.
So yeah, the whole discussion about whether he is talented is a bit off, in my view. Sturaro has a role in this squad, just like Padoin has a role. It’s not a problem that he’s not as talented as Pogba or Marchisio or Khedira, because they too have their roles. The key point here is whether he knows what his role his, and whether he’s committed to do his best and develop himself accordingly. It becomes a problem if a player doesn’t "know" or doesn’t "agree" with the coach on what his role is. Whether he can develop into a more well rounded player (more useful going forward, better at keeping the ball, etc), that remains to be seen, and I don’t see why we have to decide now.
One more thing, I have seen one clear development from Sturaro. In the past, he used to go down easily whenever on opposition gets physical with him. I’ve seen 0 incidents of that in this game.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
He has clearly developed, even in these last few games he is playing to his strengths and playing smarter. These past couple of games you can tell he has been drilled by Allegri on his role and is often seen directing others on the field regarding their position, etc. Players like Sturaro have always been a part of successful Juve sides in the past.
The attention he is getting from other teams and the dissatisfaction from other Serie A sides that Juve got him for "cheap" is a testament to this.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis

Players like Sturaro have always been a part of successful Juve sides in the past.

Also, on the topic of Max eventually getting through to his players, I was pleased to see a few instances of Juve really controlling the clock at the end of yesterday’s game. A couple times we took the ball directly to Lazio’s corner rather than making a low percentage scoring attempt. It’s the smarter play but goes against most players’ natural instincts.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
Case in point Mattiello last season, when we lost Evra and Kwadwo for a few games. Max decided to start Padoin ahead of Mattiello…because what you’re going to get out of Padoin is basically a ‘guarantee’, ie. no risk. Yet what I saw from Mattiello in his 40 mins last season was more than I’ve seen from Padoin, ever since he’s been here. In fact, I’m certain Mattiello would’ve been able to play his role at let back in those couple of games, but Max didn’t have the cojones to play him because he had Padoin there. There in lies the liability of having Padoin in the team.
I would much rather have our youth players being a back up to our back ups, even if it means seeing mistakes, errors or whatever from them. This club has such a shit track record of producing youngsters for the first team, it absolutely infuriates me, and moves like keeping Padoin around just further fuels the rage. What the hell is the point of having a primavera team if you’re never going to give them a chance? I mean, loaning them all out sure as hell isn’t working, yet you’re still never going to give them a chance in situations of emergency…because you have Simone fucking Padoin.
I swear I’ve written this word for word in numerous previous posts, beating a dead horse here.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
I absolutely and thoroughly agree that our way of managing young talents is crap. But that in my view is more a cultural issue for calcio rather than just an issue of our management. It’s going to take a lot of effort to change that, and in the mean time, we’ll have to make do with Padoin and the likes.
On a positive note, our latest trend of investing in young players (below 18) is an indication that we’re at least trying to address this issue. Like I wrote before, we only have Marchisio as home grown under UEFA definition, and that’s not good. This rule forced us to exclude Asamoah out of the UCL list during the group stage (which is fine because he was injured), and in Feb we will need to decide who to leave out in the knock out rounds (it won’t be Asa, unless he’s injured again. My guess it will be Lemina). Long term, it’s going to be an issue.
If we want to stay at the top in Europe, then we’re going to need to start "producing" some quality home grown. That’s why I believe Mandragora will not be loaned out.
This is my biggest regret re: Coman. He would have counted towards our home grown quota within 2 years had he stayed.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
What you don’t seem to get is that a player like Padoin represents that cultural isue in Calcio.
It is the management, the coaches who want a player like Padoin in their squad instead of using primavera-players (like Sampath perfectley expalined). That is a problem.
And is not only because we need them for the home grown quota. We need them because the cost isn’t high, because they breath Juve and the return can be massive.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
I understand all that. I wrote exactly the same above re: calcio culture, that it will take time to change. Even if Juve management immediately change their policy, the media, the fans, and the rest will not change overnight. The pressure on these young players will be massive, and their career can be ruined.
Of course those are the benefits of developing inhouse talents, nobody is arguing about that. I’m just saying that it won’t be a change that happens overnight, but I do have faith that the management is aware on this, and is taking steps to improve (or at least trying to do something different compared to previously).

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
Coaches aren’t always right, but it’s difficult to argue against 2 coaches that has brought so much successes in such a short time. I personally would trust them more than my own instincts, at least until proven otherwise.
Again, I agree with your overall assessment, and trust me Padoin is the first name I sell in FM. I just don’t think it’s fair to hate and crucify Padoin when he has done the job he’s being asked to do.
Re: coach who gamble more, I think Allegri is exactly that. He has shown to be willing to include primavera players in training, and bringing Vitale and the likes to matches. We do have to be realistic, though. This is a deep rooted problem and it won’t be solved just by playing primavera players more.
The fact that no Serie A clubs regularly produce their own homegrown players is a testament that this is a deep rooted problem, and an underlying solution needs to be found. I do have some ideas as to how it can be improved, although in the short term it will not be received well by the clubs. Maybe I’ll post them some other time.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis

I just don’t accept that argument. We have been so damn dominant domestically over the last few years, yet we still find ourselves stuck in the gutter with regard to the blooding of youth.

Comment Body:
17 Premier League teams feature in Deloitte’s run-down of football’s 30 richest clubs based on 2014-15 revenue – an increase of three on last year’s tally.

Each of the new arrivals, Leicester City, Crystal Palace and West Bromwich Albion, earned more money than Italian giants Napoli last season, who finished as high as 16th place 12 months ago.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
Yeah, saw that too. It seems even the lowest revenue EPL club takes in roughly €130M, in line with Napoli (5th richest Italian team). Though clearly the EPL is the most popular league in the world, I have to imagine that the current results will even out somewhat over time as new TV deals are negotiated in other leagues, etc. I expect the EPL to continue being the richest league for the foreseeable future but having 17 clubs in the top 30 is reflective of the fact they got a big head start in terms of TV money. 10 out of 30 seems a more sustainable number.
On a related topic, Pozzo certainly showed his business prowess by purchasing Watford at just the right time.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body: Not sure it would be easy to move players back and forth like you could in a parent team / reserve team scenario. I have to imagine FFP requires players to be transferred at some sort of realistic value. Not a problem if your player values don’t change but, if they increase, it could create unallowable losses in the team you want to stack. Then the sanctions come. Not to mention the problem of players having the ability to reject transfers.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
well the thing is price isnt decided by FFP and while all are own by Pozzo on paper they arent each other’s reserve/2nd team. They can just swap player for player or sell player at higher fee to ‘legitimately’ get money from one club to the other and nothing can stop him as there is no regulation that a player can be priced a certain way.
He has been managing the books well I doubt he will let the club go into unallowable losses this isnt Milanese clubs + FFP is there to make sure there isnt monopoly and club play within their limits. If City and likes can be allowed crazy sponsorship money from their subsidiaries Pozzo selling/buying players from his own clubs for +/- a few million wont create problem. I dont see players rejecting transfers too, if you a re a young player and you are transferred from one top division to another so you can play more what is the problem?

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis

Comment Body: I think you have to ask why Milan — a team making much less money than us and isn’t in the UCL — is making more from sponsorship. The other teams in Italy don’t matter as Juve is the only one whose brand transcends Serie A. We’re just not getting fair value from Jeep.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
1. If you’re only looking at our current deal, then it’s a fair assessment. But consider that Jeep invested heavily when we didn’t have European football.
2. You could almost say that this Jeep deal is an advert for our future sponsors, because the cooperation shows how 2 brands can do joint marketing in more ways than just slapping a logo on a shirt. The way Jeep gets involved in our journey, especially during pre season and in Europe is unseen before, at least from my perspective.
In any case, has anyone seen the video on how Chelsea got their current deal with Yokohama? It was amazing, but don’t take my word for it. Look at it yourselves.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
here is the latest edition of deloitte footbal money league:
http://www2.deloitte.com/content/dam/Deloitte/uk/Documents/sports-business-group/uk-deloitte-sport-football-money-league-2016.pdf
you can find the revenue of all major football clubs in this pdf. the revenues are split in 3 categories: matchday revenue, broadcast revenue and commercial revenue.
last season real, barcelona and juventus had the highest broadcast revenue (199m each). that’s tv rights, champions league money etc.
out of the top 10, we have the lowest matchday revenue (51m compared to arsenal’s 132m), even some teams outside the top ten make more than us. we’re good compared to other italian teams, but juve will never be able to compete with teams from larger cities with huge stadiums in this regard.
the term commercial revenue in deloitte football money league refers to sponsorship, merchandising and "other commercial operations". this is were we are really, really bad:
juventus 73m
…
barcelona 244m
real madrid 247m
manchester united 263m
bayern münchen 278m
(psg 297m including 200m oil money)
you’d expect us to slowly close the gap, especially with our good results in ucl last season. well, it fell from 85m in 2013/14 to 73m last season.

Comment Body:
Luckily the amount of money doesn’t matter it is what you do with that money.
English clubs have a really sad record. They can have all the money they want.
With a smart transferpolicy you can have an advantage even if you don’t have as much money as others.
So give us more Pogba’s, Rugani’s, Dybala’s and Berardi’s.

Article Title: Lazio vs. Juventus 2016: Final score 0-1, Bianconeri grind out win, advance to Coppa Italia semis
Comment Body:
Sponsorship is not the main deal here. Yes, Jeep doesn’t pay us enough, but the most important differenze with the other top teams is in the number of jerseys sold. This is due mainly to two elements:
1) Italian’s people habit to buy unofficial (illegal but cheaper) stuff
2) player’s appeal
Regarding point 2, most other top teams have bigger names that sell many many jerseys (Messi, CR7, Ibrahimovic, Lewandowski, Robben, and so on). Until 2-3 years ago, we had Giovinco and Vucinic. You can see the difference. Right now our player with the greatest appeal is probably Pogba. I think Dybala will explode quickly. As we bring in more top players, our commercial revenue will increase. I think Andrea Agnelli stated that our objective is to reach 5th place in the next 5-10 years. Projects like J-Village are also important for the future.

Comment Title: This ref is either blind or stupid.
Comment Body:
So many very stupid calls. In that 45 mins half i think the ball was actually in play for around 10mins in total, no flow to game whatsoever, and the ref has forgotten his cards in the locker room. Lazio are playing dirty and Candreva flopping like a fish didnt expect that from him but oh well.
The difference between Morata and Zaza imo atm is that Zaza is enjoying every single minute on the pitch he gets. Morata feels he needs to do too much which is preventing him from doin what he does. I hope he breaks his duck today. Its about time. I think 2-1 Juve win.

Article Title: Coppa Italia Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Lazio
Comment Body:
Had a rewatch, what a great high-tempo game. Lazio went in hard, respect, but Juve had full control. Could have scored a couple more, easy.
I was sure Hernanes would make a start, after Allegri said he’d bench Pogba again. Had everyone fooled!
Sandro looked lively at the first half, Pogba did good in stints but throughout. Morata very unlucky, but he don’t look like he’s given up or anything and that’s good. Hustle play. Cuadrado basically . . won’t be a permanent in this club.
Other than that, everyone did good. Neto, Caceres, CM8, even Sturaro could have had a goal, too.
Zaza gotta be man of the match though. He put in a crazy shift. With a bit more luck the one off the post would have went in, not that I minded that Goal Line Tech Lichtsteiner Slide Ruler Special.
FORZA JUVENTUS!!!

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
He is a starter in a competitive Italy u21 squad at the age of 18 that is impressive, I think the u21 team is yet to lose a match with him playing.
He has been likened to Thiago Motta who never reached his full potential for two reasons
1)Attitude
2)Athleticism
Mandragora doesn’t have a problem in either of those areas so I hope he can reach the level Motta could have. Mandragora has also be praised for his technique, maturity, leadership and footballing intelligence.
IF he reaches his potential he could be one the best holding midfielders in the world and could be a key member of the Juventus team for the next 10-12 years.
Mandragora
Sensi
Rugani
Sturaro
Berardi
Juventus have done a BRILLIANT job of scouting and buying the best young Italian footballers.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
At the moment, links between Juve and Sensi/Berardi are speculative. Juve could decide a totally different route this next summer, scupper the ‘plans’ they have w Berardi, and go for another attacker altogether. As for Sensi, nothing concrete links Juve to the player other than tenuous murmurs regarding the Juventus-Sassuolo relationship and generally Juve’s interest in him (along with most other ‘big’ Italian clubs, mind you).
As to your final point – sure, it is nice for Juve to buy and own some of the better young talent on the peninsula, but the club has been doing this for a long time and very few of these starlets ever end up breaking into the first team. We’ve seen how hard it is for Rugani to grab minutes and he has an entire season as a Serie A starter under his belt – Mandragora, meanwhile, is playing in lower divisions (with a few Serie A appearances sprinkled in) and may not be much more than a make-weight in future negotiations with other Italian clubs (as we have seen countless times before with similar talent).
Tl;dr – I will wait a while before getting too hyped over an 18 y/o; gotten unnecessarily hyped about too many others who didnt pan out before.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body: I would be shocked and so would everyone else if Berardi does not end up at Juventus next season and as for Sensi, Gianluca Di Marzio reported the Juventus buy option and he is as reliable as they come.

Comment Body: We’re gonna completely change formations not just for Berardi, but for us to compete more consistently, become better, and to become more balanced as a team. Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
1- Higuain IS better than Dybala, at least until now, why would you disagree? I want you to realise that he has scored more than Suarez, Ronaldo, Messi, Lewandowski, etc (in respect to their leagues), and he’s playing in Serie A, where it’s so hard to score. Higuain is definitely having one heck of a season.
2- This just shows that he dislikes Juve, and we (the fans) dislike him. It’s his own opinion, but he’s still a prick.
3- Why wouldn’t be Insigne the best Italian player? He’s performing really really good. I believe Marchisio currently is the best Italian player, but then comes a hard fight between Verratti and Insigne for the second spot.
Not defending Cassano or anything, he has said multiple stupid stuff before but these "opinions" are fairly reasonable.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body: How do you substantiate that? Balo, in just 3 year with Inter, won more than Cassano did the rest of his career. That doesn’t even include his trophies w City.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
How do you substantiate that?
I am using experience, statistics as well as Balo’s current psychological state to estimate that. But if you want more, wait for both of them to retire.
Balo, in just 3 year with Inter, won more than Cassano did the rest of his career. That doesn’t even include his trophies w City.
We all know what he "won" domestically with Inter, dont we? As for the UCL win, he was an unused sub if i recall correctly. Oh and congratu-fuckin-lations for winnings the BPL in the last minute of the season with a squad that like that!
With the opportunities that he has had, he is nothing but an utter failure. Hats off to liverpool for spending money on him. I mean, anyone with a hint of knowledge about psychology would know that he is nothing but a baby in a man’s body. He has no mind, no maturity and no desire to improve. Compared to him, Cassano feels like a mature person (what?). Now stats time: his best domestic season as a CF? 14 goals. For an elite striker, that is chump change. Cassano, a SS, had 12/15 (G/A) in his best domestic season.
Balotelli is probably the biggest waste in the world of football since that Adriano guy (inter).

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
Despite Stirpe publicly praising Leali for keeping Frosinone in the fight to stay in the top flight, rumors are swirling that they are looking at Bogdan Lobont, the 3rd string GK at Roma. Pedulla is the one who reported that, and though I don’t follow him he does have good contacts/insight when it comes to Roma.
Leali had a very poor match vs Torino, perhaps his worst game this season – he parried one ball right into the path of Belotti, and looked a bit out of position on Benassi’s goal.
My interpretation (if this is indeed accurate) is Frosinone is looking to motivate Leali and bring some competition to the training pitch, not give his job away.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
This is not going to be an easy game – especially since Lazio sees the CI as a path to European qualification given their under-performance and overall schizo season.
Too many changes (especially in the defense and midfield) would be unwarranted.A balance needs to be struck between providing quality game time to the bench (e.g. Neto), resting some key players for the upcoming critical games without loosing momentum and cohesiveness.
Assuming that 3-5-2 is the starting point, if Max decides to go with Rugani – then he needs (defensive) support from the midfield and Licht would be preferred to Cudrado. This need is even further accentuated without Gigi marshaling the defense. I am not sure how Sturaro and Rugani combination would work on the right-hand side, especially if Anderson has a good day. By the same token, Marchisio is needed to manage the defense and link-up field. To put Hernanes in the deep-lying regista (or the like) position given his past performance (lapses) and all of the other changes would be ill-advised for him and definitely for the team. He is regaining his confidence and should not be put in a position to compromise the team. Will Pogba be rested two-games in a row? Given the upcoming Roma game and Asa’s solid performance and need for game time – not highly improbable.
Looking at your list and following a "balanced" guideline:
Neto
Cacerras/Rugani Bonucci Chiellini
Sturaro/Licht Marchisio Asamoah/Hernanes Sandro
Dybala Morata/Zaza
Although one could see Mandzu and Pogba stepping in if we fall behind early.
PS – What is going on with Evra? Is max keeping him under wraps for the showdown with Bayern? While counting missing vets – what is the prognosis and return date on Barzagli?

Comment Body: That’s the idea.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
That’s kind of true Will but there are some slight differences that calling someone dumb can be used to imply that the person is stupid irrespective of whether they have the capacity to speak or hear.
It is true for instance that a technically "dumb" person cannot speak or hear.
It’s not true that homosexual people are [insert whatever derogatory term].
Dumb is a word that has a technical meaning and it also has implied meanings separate from those with the physical handicap.
On the other hand the objection to homophobia is that words equating to homosexuals are used synonymously with derogatory terms that have no connection whatsoever with being homosexual.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body: I’m not an expert on the English language, but my limited research indicates that the main difference between ‘dumb’ and other insulting words is that the transition from dumb meaning mute to stupid happened 100+ years ago.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
That’s what I meant when I said:
and it also has implied meanings separate from those with the physical handicap.
So 100 years ago the word dumb stopped being associated with physically impaired and gained its own meaning of stupid.
So when you call someone dumb you’re not being derogatory to a handicapped mute, you’re just saying someone is stupid.
Like I said below we’re not at the same point yet with other words like faggot and other homophobic or racist terms (and I can understand why we’re not) although we might be in years to come

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body: so basically what you are saying is that you are fighting progress?

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
No, I’m saying that the current meaning and use of the word is what’s relevant and if that meaning and use in current circulation is discriminatory, homophobic, racist then it’s wrong.
If ever there’s a time when the word faggot develops a clear non-homophobic meaning then maybe it will be ok (subject of course to the debate about whether it’s okay to be offensive at all).

Comment Body:
Jesus Christ, this political correctness bullshit in modern society HAS to stop.
First of all, your analogy makes no sense. It would make sense if Mancini was actually a homosexual, except that Mancini has been married to a woman for over 28 years. In no way were Sarri’s comments intended to be homophobic. Mancini is being a big old cry baby, as simple as that.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
In no way were Sarri’s comments intended to be homophobic
Sarri said similar things last year after the Varese match.
"Football has become a sport for fags," said Sarri. "We suffered twice as many fouls, but we had more yellow cards. It’s a contact sport in Italy and but the whistle is blown a lot more than in England because of the interpretation by homosexuals."
That’s what he said after the Varese match, calm while smoking a Marlboro. Problem in Italy is this sort of ignorant mentality is widespread. I highly doubt he even believes he did anything wrong in equating one’s sexuality with weakness.
Sarri’s ignorant, old school mentality makes the rest of us Italians, who actually understand the importance of treating others with decency and respect, and choosing our words with intelligence, cringe with embarrassment.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
I’ve got a policy on these things. If it’s something someone has a choice in (hair, clothes, etc.), it’s fair game. If it’s something they’re not in control of (race, sexuality, etc.), it’s inappropriate.
However, as a black guy, I’m not offended by the N-word; I frown upon it because it shows how immature or uneducated the user is. If someone says it as an insult, I call them out because I know I’ve won at that point. In their head, it’s the meanest thing they could say. Once that trump card is out and it didn’t work, I can say anything I want. If they say it by accident or non-insulting, I simply correct them because it’s a stupid word.
Typically though, there’s no need for those sensitive words. It should be embarrassing if you can’t express yourself using other, more accurate words.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body: Wise words. Your approach makes a lot of sense.

It’s a complex issue so I won’t try to simplify it but I think there are identifiable groups in the world that have been unfairly treated and we should look to end that unfair treatment. When it comes to homophobic remarks, it’s my opinion that these should not be tolerated. Time will tell how the Sarri-Mancini situation gets resolved.
Now get your short, fat, lazy, talentless ass back to work!

No one is advocating banning a word. Everyone is free to use it. I’m not speaking for censorship.
Like you said, it is frowned upon and it is ignorant. Now because of that…the problem is that people aren’t free from the repercussions from using a word as an insult towards another especially in a professional setting, when that governing body of that setting the Lega, TIM CUP or whatever sanction insults towards another person.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
I think this is really short sighted Will.
Grave grave injustices have been done to blacks, homosexuals and many other parts of societies and races.
Any measures to fix this hatred and damage done by it is welcomed by me.
It’s easy to say someone’s being over sensitive when upset by words but the undercurrent of serious serious injustices that have been done to these parts of societies is real.
There may come a time when it can all be joked about or brushed off but I don’t think we’re there yet.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
We’re not there yet because the PC police and professional victims refuse to let us get there.
Any measures to fix this hatred and damage done by it is welcomed by me.
Banning words won’t fix any injustices. Furthermore, you seem more inclined to ban the thoughts behind the words than the words themselves. Clearly if one word becomes too dangerous to say or falls out of fashion, a new one will take its place. I suppose you would also suspend him if he called Mancini a homo?
Sarri was intentionally insulting Mancini, it was offensive on purpose. I don’t see why it matters how he chose to insult him. Either it’s okay to insult someone on a football pitch or it isn’t. Was what Materazzi said to Zidane less offensive than what Sarri said?

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
We’re not there yet because the PC police and professional victims refuse to let us get there.
We’re not there yet because people continue to discriminate against blacks, gays, races, etc etc. people still bash people for being gay.
And with this backdrop it’s completely understandable that there are PC police and victims that refuse to let it go.
Re the Sarri incident, you have to have some standard which you hold people up to. One part of that is anti-discrimination a part of which is not using discriminatory words eg homophobic, racist etc.
You then say – well why shouldn’t we ban anything offensive?
I guess I’d split things into two categories. One is discrimination and the other is offensive behavior.
1. With discrimination we’re trying to protect particularly under threat sections of community and unequal practices that’s why certain specific topics/areas are banned and we try to prevent derogatory words in this realm to stop the currents in society that encourage bad behavior against these sections of the community.
2. Offensive behavior – The being offensive part is kind of tricky. Whether or not it’s okay to be offensive outside the realm of discrimination (and what constitutes being offensive) is a grey area. Eg it’s okay to say "You’re a hopeless coach" but may not be ok to say "You’re mother is a slut". This one’s a whole area of debate as you allude to with the Zidane incident but is separate to discrimination if it’s not involving the use of discriminatory behavior or words.
I mean I’m thinking this through as I go but there are whole bodies of law and thought on this issue that I’m pretty sure work along these lines.
There’s a reason we have anti-discrimination laws and the human rights treaties etc. To discourage discrimination and discriminatory behavior and I think a professional sportsperson like Sarri calling another coach a faggot (or insert any other homophobic word) as a derogation is running contrary to that whole body of thought.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Title: There was a 'case' in Australia a few years ago
Comment Body:
Where a talent show was performed with 5 white people disguising themselves as the jackson 5 and lip-sync one of their songs. They did the same act a year ago and won it, but that year a guest judge from USA (I think it was Harry Connick Jr.) was invited in the show, saw the act, and blast the performance as ‘racist’.
Now a question: was the performance a dig on all black people? No it’s not, it’s a dig on Jackson 5. Wouldn’t you agree he was simply enforcing his view based on his own culture and experiences? This shouldn’t be any more offensive than Justin Timberlake dressing like Jessica Simpson and actually insulted her intelligence on the Oscars (don’t ask me when, but I’ve seen it; I’d argue that was more offensive than this)
All of this is not supposed to be saying that he’s to blame for thinking that way, but… discrimination is perceived in different ways by different people and it affects people in different ways. The moment you try to regulate it, you run into all kinds of problems, because anything you say CAN offend anyone and eventually nobody is happy. Unfortunately the 2 categories you tried to split isn’t very much split in that law you talk about, because now a case for ‘offense’ can be moved into ‘discrimination’, simply by considering WHO was offended.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
I’m having a bit of trouble trying to understand the point you’re trying to make Benedict.
I certainly don’t agree with your implication that you shouldn’t regulate discrimination because discrimination can be perceived differently by different people. That’s no reason to allow discriminatory behavior. It just means lines need to be drawn as objectively as possible about what’s discrimination and what’s not.
I’ll post below the relevant section of the Australian Discrimination Act which tries to do that.
Re your Jackson 5 example it’s hard to see how that would be objectively discriminatory if they just dressed up and sang like them. If they did things that were clearly aimed at mocking black people in their routine then that might be another story.
Interestingly Australia has an exception for artistic performances provided they are done in good faith.
The JT Jessica Simpson example is a good one to show the distinction between offensive and discriminatory. As far as I can tell he was just mocking / being offensive to her directly not based on any of the discriminatory categories like race, religion, sex etc.
So to me it demonstrates the potential difference between the Jackson 5 incident and the JT incident.
You said:
Unfortunately the 2 categories you tried to split isn’t very much split in that law you talk about, because now a case for ‘offense’ can be moved into ‘discrimination’, simply by considering WHO was offended.
But the two cases are quite clearly split in the law. A case for offense can only be part of discriminatory laws if it falls within one of those categories of discrimination such as race, religion, gender etc.
Here are sections 18C and D of the Racial Discrimination Act 1975 (Australia) which are an interesting read. It’s a bit hard to read here so here’s a link as well
section 18C
Section 18D
18C Offensive behaviour because of race, colour or national or ethnic origin

(1) It is unlawful for a person to do an act, otherwise than in private, if:

(a) the act is reasonably likely, in all the circumstances, to offend, insult, humiliate or intimidate another person or a group of people; and

(b) the act is done because of the race, colour or national or ethnic origin of the other person or of some or all of the people in the group.

……

18D Exemptions

Section 18C does not render unlawful anything said or done reasonably and in good faith:

(a) in the performance, exhibition or distribution of an artistic work; or

(b) in the course of any statement, publication, discussion or debate made or held for any genuine academic, artistic or scientific purpose or any other genuine purpose in the public interest; or

© in making or publishing:

(i) a fair and accurate report of any event or matter of public interest; or

(ii) a fair comment on any event or matter of public interest if the comment is an expression of a genuine belief held by the person making the comment.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
I’d also add that I think it’s incorrect to say:
now a case for ‘offense’ can be moved into ‘discrimination’, simply by considering WHO was offended.
It’s not just a question of who was offended but the subject matter of the offense must be discriminatory.
A black person can be offended without it being racially discriminatory.
Eg I could offend a black person by saying "You are an idiot". That’s offensive but not racially discriminatory.
On the other hand it would be racially discriminatory if I said "You’re an idiot because you’re black."
Discrimination laws and ideas are generally about judging and treating people based on their own qualities rather than prejudging them or categorizing them based on their race, religion, sex etc.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Title: yeah I get where you draw the line, and objectively I agree
Comment Body:
it’s just my opinion (albeit cynical, I admit) that it doesn’t work that way with most people. When you’re personally involved, you bring your own feeling into it, and interpretation of such feelings are never sufficiently objective. Nowadays even media plays huge part in deciding a case, or failing that, a public perception of the case. Even if the case was thrown out as per the law, the public still judges them.
and this is not to mention that now you’ll have a criminal record for something you may have ignorantly said when you were 20, for example… and still be considered a racist 20 years on. I mean, this is the case with most other offenses such as murders, stealing etc. but criminal record simply on the basis of what you said(drunk, emotional, etc.)? that still seemed excessive…

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body: I get what you’re saying.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Title: Actually your explanation gets very close to my point
Comment Body:
which I admit isn’t very well articulated, but my point with Harry Connick Jr.‘s example is this: He is offended by their performance, and he claimed it on discriminatory grounds, in other words ’I am offended because I think this performance is insulting on all black people’. Now, at the moment I have to assume that the majority would have disagreed with him and should he brought it to the court it will be summarily dismissed, but feelings and opinions can shift over time and so does the law. We’ve already seen some people trying to ban prayers on a private christian school because they’re atheists yet they want to put their kids there, and at some point our state government actually granted that request!
in a perfect world, the law will be made objectively. Unfortunately, governments are elected by most popular votes. And policies are more often made not for the sake of justice, but to garner support.
By no means am I implying that we should not regulate it at all, I’m just pointing out a glaring consequences of these laws which a lot of people abuse as the other side of the coin.
But, I will be the first to admit that I’m no expert on this.

Article Title: OFFICIALLY OFFICIAL: Juventus sign midfielder Rolando Mandragora from Genoa
Comment Body:
Sarri was intentionally insulting Mancini, it was offensive on purpose. I don’t see why it matters how he chose to insult him. Either it’s okay to insult someone on a football pitch or it isn’t. Was what Materazzi said to Zidane less offensive than what Sarri said?
Isn’t the difference that the fourth official and people on the bench heard the interaction between Sarri and Mancini?
The incident between Zidane and Materazzi, no one else (like the ref) could corroborate what was said, so Materazzi was not penalized. Materazzi is a jerk but this was done on purpose while no one else was around so he couldn’t be penalized. It was Zidane’s word vs. his and only one of them reacted in a way that was seen and penalized.
Players are given second yellow cards and red cards all the time for swearing at the ref. Wasn’t Pandev sent off in the Supercoppa for this 2 years ago because the linesman heard him swear at the ref?
Stuff like this happens all the time but if you do it while the ref is around and hears you, expect to be penalized.

Article Title: Juventus manager Max Allegri says Paulo Dybala, Carlos Tevez comparisons aren't fair
Comment Body:
Feeling more and more confident that we can hang with FC Bayern, I was feeling like a 30% chance to beat them when we got them in the draw. But 10 straight wins now, most of the team healthy, Pereyra coming back amd Dybala playing out of his mind? Its going to be a toss up.
If we beat them, you have to think of Juve as the second best team in Europe, only behind Barcelona IMO.

Article Title: Juventus manager Max Allegri says Paulo Dybala, Carlos Tevez comparisons aren't fair
Comment Body:
Bayern always seem have an extra gear in their transmission. We have to be at our optimum best to overcome them. I have faith though.
Forza Juve!!!

Article Title: Juventus manager Max Allegri says Paulo Dybala, Carlos Tevez comparisons aren't fair
Comment Body:
Is a pleasure to watch the rise of many youngsters and how they display their quality, even more enjoyable to showcase to the world you dont need all the money in the world to make a team. You need people whos different atributes come together and form an institution that has a vision and a plan for the future. I love Juve, but I really love the idea to watch how this lads are being molded into a caliber of champion, I did not get to witness Del Pieros rise but this season marks the beginning of a new page to add to the already illustrious career of the best club in the world.
Cheers to Allegri, Nedved, Agnelli, Marotta and all the others working behind the scenes to make it possible.
Oh and did you see Alex Sandro? What a gol.!

Article Title: Juventus manager Max Allegri says Paulo Dybala, Carlos Tevez comparisons aren't fair
Comment Body:
Maturity developed later in life for me. With the many things i missed cuz of being a child was watching juve play. I do now watch every match, and i visit this site to the point im afraid i might be obsessed. My point is i feel unlucky that when i did start to enjoy watching juve and reading up on juve matters, ADP isnt here
I just hope i can 1 day make all my soical media accounts profile pictures of me taking a selfie with the legend.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
Lemina will be bought. He will replace Padoin, whose contract is set to expire at the end of the season. Lemina is as versatile as Padoin, he has played as a CM, CDM, CB, and RB.
Berardi will replace Cuadrado, who will likely return to Chelsea at the end of the season because we have no option to buy him. Berardi can either play as a RW, or possibly be tested in a CAM role, as Allegri has already talked about the option of playing Berardi behind the strikers. Berardi and Pereyra will alternate for the TQ role next season.
I don’t see Morata going back to RM at the end of the season unless if Zidane somehow convinces Morata to return. With the current form of BBC, Morata will find it very hard to break into the first team. If one of BBC leaves, RM will most likely buy a marketable striker (i.e. Aguero) who can not only score goals but also sell t-shirts and sponsorship deals

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: I had a good chuckle on Sunday when he came on. The commentators gave a little cheer and said that juventini love seeing him come in because that means the game is well in hand.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
Fact: We have won 100% of games in which Padoin comes in as a sub around the 80th minute when we are in a leading position by 2 goals or more.
Him coming in is Allegri’s (and previously Conte’s) way of declaring to the opposition that they no longer have any chance of salvaging anything from the match.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
haha I totally expected this comment. But Lemina may even be more versatile than Padoin. Padoin has played in several roles:
CM
CDM
RWB
LWB
Whereas Lemina has played in the following roles:
CM
CDM
RB
CB (in a 3 CB’s set up)
Therefore, Lemina is more versatile than Padoin

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
Padoin has played both fullback roles as well as wingbacks IIRC. Last year he played LB numerous times and RB when Licht needed a break and Martin was hurt.
Not that it matters but Padoin is King of Versatility, let’s let him have that

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
Padoin has been utilized as vice-Pirlo and vice-Marchisio…
TOP THAT!!!

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: Trump – Padoin 2016

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: Someone please Photoshop a campaign banner of this.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
Lemina might have played in those positions, but that was at Marseille. Juve is at a different level, the focus put on tactical details is way higher. Padoin on the other hand has proven that he can fulfill Allegri’s demand to be a viable backup in at least 3 positions. Your or my opinion in this matter is irrelevant.
Case in point: Caceres is a consistent performer at LB for Uruguay, but he has never played there for us. Another example in reverse, Sturaro whom I don’t recall ever played RB was actually the one player that Allegri has publicly stated as capable in covering for Licht there, not Lemina.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: I honestly think that Padoin’s versatility comes from the fact that he is so bad that he didn’t "own" a position yet.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
If you compare him to the first teamers, of course he’s bad. But he’s here as the backup. And as the backup, he’s fine.
In any case, hate him all we want, the fact is that he’s valued by both Conte and Allegri. If you don’t have any faith in Padoin, you should at least have faith in Conte and Allegri.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: I don’t hate Padoin? Just explaining why he plays in almost every position on the pitch; it’s because he doesn’t have any.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
True that he doesn’t excel in a single position, but it’s also true that he has shown to be capable playing different roles as per the coach’s requirement.
Do not ignore the second part.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: Not ignoring it, it’s what he’s good at. He’s a back-up for other back-ups.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
Padoin’s versatility comes from the fact that he is so bad that he didn’t "own" a position yet.
This is so wrong, if that was the case the average players we had before would hv played everywhere. His versatility comes from tactical intelligence which is why before hernanes and Lemina was purchased Allegri only trusted him as vice marchisio.
His understanding of the game is great and at the same time his understanding of his limitations. He will be a good coach.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
I hope you’re right.
If we do replace Padoin with Lemina man this squad really is upgrading.
Other than TQ (or maybe even including TQ if you consider Pogba an option then) we have fantastic back up options for pretty much every position on the pitch.
Throw in a couple of moves in summer and we will have an amazing first XI plus depth. Yes like the ocean.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: We just can’t have 3 of our top players dip on us next year and we’ll have an unstoppable squad. Think about if we added another batch of upgrades to this squad we have now.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
I’d buy Lemina for sure if we’re confident about his injury status.
He is young and has shown he has talent and an outstanding head on his shoulders.
Early season when all was difficult he actually looked like he belonged whenever he was called in to play.
I think he’s got a great career ahead of him.
Unfortunately the poor bloke is not getting the chance to show it.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
He’s sorta heading the way Romulo did at the moment. Showing glimpses in each performances and his return from injury has been apparently imminent for a long while now, but he still hasn’t returned, frustratingly.
Personally, I think it’s well known around here I rate him higher than Sturaro, but for whatever reason he’s below him in the pecking order it seems. With Kwadwo’s return too, I don’t see him getting enough playing time. This probably means, at the moment, I think it’s currently more likely than less likely that we won’t sign him on a permanent basis unfortunately.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
I’m with our Zen Master on this. While he’s shown promise when he played on his debut, I think in his last couple of games he didn’t really play well. I do note that it was during the time when the whole team struggled, and being a new player it is expected that he won’t suddenly perform week in week out. I’m just saying that it’s too early to judge him, and unfortunately for him, the way we depend on Pogba, Khedira, and Marchisio, and with Asamoah gaining fitness and Hernanes practically Allegri’s 1st choice as vice Claudio, I don’t think we’ll see much of Lemina from now on.
Add to that the signing of Mandragora for 7mil (indicating he’ll be part of the 1st team next season), and I honestly doubt we’ll sign Lemina permanently.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
I thought he was very solid playing at the base of the midfield vs Genoa…I hope he’ll be the vice-Marchisio when he comes back
Regarding Mandragora, I just think the fee we spent on him indicates how highly management think of his potential, but I’m very doubtful he’ll be anywhere near the first team next season, especially given he has next to no experience playing in Serie A.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
He covers the defense well, but he’s still way off in terms of regulating the play like Claudio. And it seems that Hernanes (much to your dismay) has eclipsed him in the pecking order as vice Marchisio. Since he wasn’t very effective as mezz’alla, I doubt he’ll get much chance to showcase his ability.
Re Mandragora: Marotta and Agnelli doesn’t really believe in loaning players for development. They’ve been quoted to say that loaning is a guaranteed way to lose control over player development. When they loan players, it’s usually to advertise them to potential buyers. If they want to develop the player, it’s usually the Sensi route.
In any case, I understand that it’s too early to speculate what will happen to Rolando. The management will likely decide after the preseason. And if Pescara is promoted to Serie A next season (don’t know where they are in the Serie B table right now), I think they will consider loaning him back to Pescara, as long as the coach remains unchanged.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: Oh yeah of course, he’s nothing like Claudio, Lemina plays like a genuine defensive/holding mid at the base of midfield

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
I thought Lemina at centre mid was outstanding. He looked very comfortable on the ball, new his surroundings and kept possession ticking over nicely. He looked far more comfortable there than say Hernanes.
I thought he kept the game ticking over brilliantly when he played there.
I don’t think Sampath was saying he’s not worthy – I think he was just saying the reality is with his injury and our depth he probably won’t get to play enough to justify keeping him. Which is really unfortunate cos I think he is a great prospect.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: Our admiration to his display likely came from the fact that we had quite a low expectation, or maybe even no expectation at all. The question is whether he can perform as well as he did every time he’s called upon. I liked him as well back then, but I’m not going to say yet thay he’s worthy of Juve. And unfortunately, I think his chances to prove that he is worthy will be very few, which I think is the same message from Zenpath.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
I can’t stand this mentality from Juventus fans, we don’t buy talented young players, train them up for a few years then sell them on for profit, we buy young players to build the team around going forward for the next 6-8 years.
That is something clubs like Wolfsburg, Porto, Monaco etc… Have this policy. Juventus are one of the biggest clubs in the world and we have ambition.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
It’s not really Juventus fans. It’s them EPL clubs and the big 2 La Liga teams, alongside the media that speculates around them. They live in an ultra-capitalistic bubble devoid of any social institutions, like that of trust. Loyalty? Pfft, Pogba will definitely move to a club that shall pay him more!
Unfortunately we live in a Serie A bubble, where one-club men live. In an era with Del Piero, Buffon, Trezeguet, Totti, Maldini, Marchisio, Chiellini, De Rossi, Gillet, heck even Di Natale; players who don’t leave for lucrative offers, or stay with clubs that don’t remain in Serie A. Funny how a league perceived as constantly "cheating", have men with more honour then these other leagues!

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Title: The English clubs along with Real Madrid and Barcrlona
Comment Body: are single handedly responsible for the silly amount of inflation in the transfer market over the past 10 years or so. Martial is nowhere near worth that much. If Martial sells for 75 then Dybala is worth well over 100.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
Then Marotta and Paratici should be responsible for devaluation in the transfer market by selling these players:
1. Arturo Vidal, €37M
2. Kingsley Coman, €7M (LWOTB)
3. Carlos Tevez, €6,5M (no money in the transaction)
4. Fernando Llorente, Free (contract terminated)

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: The last 2 aren’t fair. We were operating for the best of Tevez’s career and happiness while Fernando was on humongous wages, coming off a brutal (still love him) year, and only wanted to return to Spain.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: I still miss Llorente, those are the kind of players that make Juve great and I see that in Dybala

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: Can’t believe I forgot about United’s shenanigans.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: And really it’s United who just got the shenanigans started. I expect many other clubs to follow suit shortly, particularly in the EPL where a lucrative new TV deal is about to kick in. If Bournemouth can splash €20-25M on Iturbe, there’s no telling what Chelsea, United, City, Arsenal, Spurs, etc. will be able to spend on a real talent like Dybala. I think we’re about to see a "new normal" in terms of player valuations which makes Beppe & Co’s drive for all the promising Italian youth all the more wise.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body: As a United fan, I would say United got the shenanigans started all the way back in 2002 and 2004 when they spent £29.1m on Rio Ferdidnand and £27m on an 18 year old Rooney.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Title: I remembered the record signing in the world in '98
Comment Body:
was 21m Pounds for a brazilian called Denilson… by a club called Real Betis
considering inflation and everything, I’d say in comparison Man U’s transfers were still cheap and sensible.
nah, I’d say shenanigans really started when Abramovich bought chelsea and gave ranieri free reign to sign anyone at any price. He ended up signing many average players for world class fee.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Title: This is where the good prices became stupid and the stupid became.. Well even more stupid.
Comment Body: Mutu, Crespo, Makelele, Duff, Parker, Veron, Smertin, Bridge and Geremi. These players where all brought for ridiculous ammounts £120m, and i have to agree with you. This is when the stupid prices became more stupid.

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
Abramobitch came much later in ~2003. Before this, there were many expensive purchases such as Zidane and Figo.
I wouldn’t say that the amounts paid for Mutu, Crespo, and Makelele to be stupid. Granted, idk how much they exactly paid for them for these 3 players were beasts at that time and deserved to be purchased by a large sum. Makelele was an absolute beast for RM and RM would go on for several unsuccessful seasons because they essentially didn’t bring anyone on his quality to replace him. Crespo was one of the best Serie A strikers and Mutu was a great young talent who had the chance to be a great player if it wasn’t for his drugs problems

Article Title: Rolando Mandragora undergoing Juventus medical
Comment Body:
at least you could have reasonable arguments for these transfers before. zidane were the best player in world cup and euro cup winner team, and figo is the best player in a rival club, you can see why their prices are up the wall. Even Man u’s 12m pound signing of dwight yorke brought them treble.
back to chelsea though, I actually say the signings they made from outside of england isn’t that bad, they’re generally good value… but those in england… Glenn Johnson(6.3m), Veron(15m), Wayne Bridge(7m), Scott Parker(10m), and Damien Duff(17m) actually signed for more than those 3 aforementioned legends(mutu 15.8m, crespo 16.8m, makalele 16m). From then on, you won’t get any players worth their salt from epl middle clubs to sell for less than 10m.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Well, not much to say, honestly. Incredible performances by Dybala and Khedira, tied for man of the match, but also the incredible work by Mandzukic should be noted. Sandro was great as well. He had tried that move (going into the area from the left and shooting with the right) a couple of times in past games, this time he got it right.
Khedira in particular had looked a little slow in the last game, but he was amazing today.
This was a good game for Morata to score, but it seems that his bad period will continue a little more (I hope he can score on wednesday against lazio).
Second half we practically didn’t play, and even then we could have scored another couple of goals. Otherwise this could have ended like 8-0. But whatever, it doesn’t matter. Still, it would have been fun to see Zaza in a game like this, considering that he always wants to break the world when he plays.
The real game is next Sunday. We win and definitely kill Roma.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations

Thank you apajohnson and Nernie for your effort and the Reddit site.
I usually find highlights on Youtube and that satisfies my nephew’s Buffon (SuperGG) inspired fantasies. Interestingly this has been his favorite .
We have tried watching the Juve games ‘live’ together, but it is not easy. After the first Pogba or Dybala touch on the ball the game is paused for him to reenact (replay) the move that either ends in a Pogbooom or a Deeee-bala Goa1 – and sometimes both! The viewing stops completely after a Gigi-save where the Super-GG cape comes out and he is diving (flying) across the room. From live to lively.
But again we always go back to the interview by the giovoni Juventini , where SuperGG is being Buffon.
