Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Title: Notts County and Udinese: Inaugural Games & Lo Stile Juve
Comment Body:
Thank you SD.
The opening inaugural game in Turn was fully sponsored/covered by Juve – including expenses for Notts County. Juve was hosting a very special team and institution in all of football and especially for the Bianconneri. A perfect Inaugural celebration of Juve, its history and calcio.
The game today was a regular (and very important) Serie A match. And – historically speaking we needed to beat the team that was responsible for Juve’s loss in an opening-home game for the first time in its history. Call it reciprocal historical justification to win in one of their historical (albeit fresh) events. Second half – respect Udinese and take the foot off the pedal.
In BOTH cases – Lo Stile Juve

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
"A lot of people call me a mercenary, and they are right. I always promise that I will stay with the same team forever but then money always changes my mind. I left Juve because of money. They were going to serie B and I wasn’t guaranteed a higher wage.
But at Juventus it was beautiful. It was different. Maybe I would have stayed if we weren’t relegated in serie B. I know fans don’t like it and i don’t like it either but that’s how i am. I like to make as much money as I can. Sometimes I have said unpleasant things about Juve, but I was playing in Italy. I wasn’t allowed to say good things about Juve. I was told to bad-mouth Juve.
Now that i play in France, I can say what I really feel. To wear the Juve jersey was a different feeling. The thought that I was playing for Juve gave me a lot of emotions."
-Ibrahimovic the day he signed for PSG

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Not hard to imagine that James is not be far behind. Zidane’s preferences seem to be pretty clear. But again amd aside from the rumor-factories, these big moves in the Winter mercato are very rare. The top-level teams need quality and depth as they go into the second half of multi-cup competitions. It is to fortify rather than funding a major buy.
In the case of Real – with the loss of Modric last year they had to resort to Ramos to cover. It happens when Galactico jersey sales translate into limited tactical nightmares on the pitch.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
The likelihood of him leaving PSG is high. They are ready to move malcontento. He was on the bench for the Toulouse game on Saturday looking for the exit sign.
The issue is not limited to the significant transfer fee, but the impact the high salary level will have on the pay structure. Independent of Cavani (or the like) Juve must up their salaries to lessen and remove the financial incentive for the current players to leave for $$$-pastures. TO prepare for the Summer mercato – Juve will be renegotiating many contracts this winter/Spring. Morata’s was the first of many.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Just like every club they have to play by the FFP rules… It is NOT the money they need, it is the fact that they need to show it in their accounts that they are not borrowing money for their signing… And that it’s the money they’ve gained from the sale of their players…And Yes, Surprise Suprise, Madird is buried to his neck in debt….
Despite all of that, whether I believe it or NOT was not the point of my post.. the main point was that Real wouldn’t let him go for cheap.. Higuain, di Maria, Ozil, all of those players were sold for big sums…. and the kind of money they ask for him is not what Juve will pay for a player like Toni Kroos.. Now that is what the point of that post was.
On a separate note, I had promised myself that I would always avoid responding back to this "mind-of-child-trapped-in-man’s-body"… guess promises are meant to be broken.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
we seem more inclined to spend moderate amounts on younger players
It’s not tht there was a huge discussion between fefu and Paolo in summer’s on June’s transfer policies regarding this.
Basically we currently can either afford to offer high transfer fee and low/average wage (dybala and sandro) or low/average transfer fee and high wage (khedira, pirlo, llorente, Morata) . We are not rich enough to pay high transfer fee and high wage which is why we don’t get into bidding wars.
We can easily pay the price set by selling club like other top clubs but the price us out in the wage department.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
I would rather move away from the slow imobile
Yea, that’s why we sold him to Dortmund a while ago.
On a serious note, I would probably agree that we could move away from a slow regista type, but it seems Max is insistent on playing one and if that’s the case then Kroos would be an absolute outstanding addition to the midfield.
The thing I don’t love about treq is that barring a few that can play on the wing effectively, they’re pretty limited tactically. Most of the better ones like Ozil (he’s proved me wrong this season), Gotze, Mata, etc., are pretty limited to that spot in the hole.
All things considered, I’d say buy either a treq or regista depending on who is available, just get the better player. If Kroos is available, get him. If Isco/J-Rod is available, get him. All are unlikely but in theory that can be applied to other players, that’s the sort of thing I think we should be doing.

Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body: The only main reason for that, was that it relegated Pereyra to the bench. Solely for the purpose of having our four "best" midfielders on the pitch at once. Had that been two years ago, it might’ve made more sense, because two seasons back, Vidal was a lethal goal scoring machine. He was kinda wasted last year in that advanced position. More so, I thought we looked a lot more impressive and fluid with Vidal and Pogba playing besides Marchisio as the regista, Pirlo on the bench, and Pereyra slotting in behind Tevez and Morata last year, on the whole.

I wouldn’t elevate him over any current starter. We have no starting slot for him in a 3-5-2, and in a 4-4-2, I’d rather see the extra midfield spot go to Cuadrado.

Not worth the formation change to accommodate Pereyra, whom I like, but don’t believe is centerpiece-quality player for a squad with aspirations like ours.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body: Juve played its best football with Pereyra in the hole behind the strikers, Vidal in his normal position and Marchisio as the fulcrum in the midfield. It was not Max’s preferred formation, but it was the best Juve has looked. Pereyra is not a perfect player but his interpretation of the role and the attributes he does possess made Juve a juggernaut. I was hoping that with the departure of Pirlo, Max would return to that set up.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
I disagree with having our four best midfielders on the field at the same time, if it means one of them is playing out of position. And yes, Vidal is amazing. But his influence on the game is far far less when he’s playing at TQ. I can think of so many occasions where his B2B instincts kicked in while both defending and attacking, in terms of his positioning, and he had to stop to check his movement and hustle back to where he ought to be. Couple this with the fact that Pirlo had a pretty poor year, and his playing away from his best position (And I mean BEST position, because no one can convince me that there was a better B2B in the world than Arturo from 2012-2014) meant that he never really played himself out of the psuedo funk he was in, and I still stand by my opinion that I don’t think all 4 on the pitch at once was our best formation. Yes, he wasn’t really doing anything wrong, but his performances levels were incredibly low as compared to the lofty standards he set for himself in his first three years at the club. I suppose when you’re defending a slender lead away to Madrid, starting the game with the vastly more defensively sound Vidal and not Pereyra makes sense, considering he can be a goal threat to score a sucker punch too.
And as Donzia added above me, Pereyra was absolute dynamite. He offers a directness and intuitive playing style that kinda raises the game of everyone around him. When he’s on the pitch, and on song (granted: he isn’t the MODEL of consistency), our attack looked so much more fluid. Case in point, I don’t think anyone is going to convince me that he wasn’t our best player for the first horrid month of this season. Through our struggles, he was the only one creating both goals and goal scoring chances for his teammates. He is so vastly underrated.. I definitely remember voicing my opinion here multiple times in the second half of last season, that the 4-3-1-2 with a MVP midfield trio (Pogba, not Pirlo), and Pereyra supporting the top two was our best playing XI.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
I see what you’re saying Kaushik, I really do. I’m actually inclined to agree with most of your points, however, you need to look at it from Allegri’s position.
Imagine him not playing Pirlo in a big CL game like the final, and starting the lesser known Pereyra. If he loses any sort of big match with Pirlo on the bench, he would get absolutely slaughtered by the press, fans and likely even the board. Not saying it’s justified at all, I just think that’s what would have happened.
Pirlo was the worst of our MVPP quartet last year, that much I think everyone can agree with, but being the legend he is, I just couldn’t see Max voluntarily benching him in a big game.
So really, it was probably down to playing one of Vidal, Marchisio or Pogba out of position vs. Pereyra in position. I’d still probably choose the former.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
I totally agree, haha. After a season like that, I’m not going to question Max and his methods at all. I was just answering your question regarding my justification as to why I wasn’t thrilled with Vidal playing TQ.
That said, the idea of Pogba supporting the front two, with Khedira-Marchisio-Asamoah/Sturaro behind him, intrigues me.. Atleast Khedira and Asamoah are the kinds who roam around very intelligently, and sprout in very interesting positions while attacking. I think Pogba has what it takes to thrive there, and form a brilliant partnership with the deep-dropping Dybala. I still think that his best position is B2B though. He’s crucial in taking the ball out of our half, and his defensive play and positioning has improved by leaps and bounds. Besides that, he has formed an almost telepathic understanding with both Evra and Sandro, not to mention Chiellini. We lose a lot of that if we push him forward. I would wholly support the idea of Pereyra starting in the hole in front of our best midfield trio (KMP), and when we don’t have Roberto, experiment with pushing Pogba ahead, or play the 3-5-2.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
Juventus belongs on top of the italian league, and it does not matter much if that ruins serie a, because the future of european football is inevitably going to be reformed into a european super league sooner or later.
I am all for this because frankly I think it is too bad that one of bayern and juve will have to shelve their european winning ambitions for the season in the round of 16.
A super league consisting or the 20 best european teams playing each other every week has to be the future.
Agnelli and Rummenigge both commented on this last week. They laid out the numbers and they were both strong advocates of a super league.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body: The premier league would vote heavily against it. It would marginalize every small team and they would completely lose out on the tv deal they have now thus resulting in huge loss of income. It would require some major deliberations and forward movement for this to happen.

Article Title: Juventus 4 - Udinese 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
I’d say the German league is worse than this, not only is Bayern Munich the only team with any kind of sustained dominance, but they kept signing key players from their rivals, directly weakening their competition. There are only 2 teams in La Liga with a sustained champions credentials with a rotated 3rd team every 5 years, and epl is decided by who decides to spend more money that year (Man U this year aside).
But there will always be teams that rise up to their challenges, since unable to compete with money means they have to compete through other means, and gems are found. The better juve gets, the higher the ceiling is. from the league standing point of view the league might look stale, but if you compare it by competitions and each team’s quality, they’re leaps and bounds from the fiasco of 06-07. Juve showed how to run a football club. Some clubs are more dense than others(really how long does it take city rivals to realise they’re better off with separate stadiums?), but those who learns from juve improved heaps. The only reason why juve still stands supreme is because it stays ahead strategically above everyone else. The day we become complacent for a second is the day we’ll lose the league.
tl;dr: Juve can win the league for the next decade, and serie A is still heading on the right track

Comment Body: There was someone here asking whether we can filter out some ID’s on comment sections. Anyone knows how?

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Udinese
Comment Body: I’d tell you if I knew how

Article Title: Game Time Thread: Juventus vs. Udinese
Comment Body:
to repeat myself and add some thoughts to entertain that idea:
no i don’t think it is possible with current system SBN have. nor i think they will ever make it possible unless they completely revamp the commenting system. with 3rd party solution (e.g. browser extension/add-on), technically possible since it’s all about document element’s visibility
however let’s talk hypothetically: what do you have in mind when you "filter out" a certain user? do their writings just gone (in your display), or more like toggle-able visibility, defaulting to hidden (but you can still click them to read). what about the chain of replies? should it follow the rule on ‘parent’ comment (when the parent is hidden or gone, so are all the replies under it. just like now when a comment is removed by mod), or the replies would still be visible (like current disqus, for example).
and, the game’s back on

Comment Body:

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body: Didn’t think twice. Buffon for the accountability and focus he commanded. A leader like him was necessary for this team to stop their early season fuckery – tho I’m not sure that’s a WhoScored category.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
Such a tough one this year. Which is actually a good sign – we are more of a team this year than last year where we relied heavily on eg Tevez.
You could make a case for many of them.
Buffon – strong as always. Probably hasn’t had to do enough to vote him MVP.
Dybala – he got my vote although I could easily have voted for others. He was consistently high standard throughout the first half.
Pogba – he’s also hard to go passed. Yes he was poor early on, but there was so much pressure on him. Once he got going he looks his incredible self with strength skill and everything else a footballer needs. He’s even added that TQ ability to feed some great passes.
Marchisio – What can you say? Once he came back we’ve been winning again. The unseen key to our team that keeps us ticking over.
Chiellini – I was almost tempted to vote for him. I’ve gotta say I was so impressed with him live the three times I saw him. He absolutely hounds the shit out of defenders and does everything you don’t want as a striker.
Mandzukic – He did come good and score some important goals but too inconsistent with his bad patch probably doesn’t deserve the vote in my opinion.
Others who deserve an honorable mention probably include Sandro and Bonucci.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
I think it’s possible for a player to look good / play well and the team suffer.
When watching the games earlier in the season i always felt as if the team play broke down with Cuadrado even though he could look good with his dribbling etc.
Remember the debate – is Cuadrado all huff and puff with no end product?
To me he’s a conundrum. Can look good but not actually produce much and be detrimental to the team.
When I was watching Juve Palermo in Palermo it was really interesting to see how when Cuadrado came on he seemed heaps out of sync with the team and Max spent most of his time berating his positional play and choices from the sideline.
Don’t get me wrong, I think Cuadrado can be good and is not bad as RWB but I think he can be a very individualistic player (it’s just his game) and play can lose momentum and direction when the ball goes to him.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
Not sure why you’re disagreeing with him. Real Madrid won the CL in 2013/14 because they finally did something right for once – hiring a competent fucking manager. And having a balance in midfield between attack and defense helped a lot, too.
But, of course, Perez effed it all up by selling what defensive minded players they did have to make space for shiny new toys like James and Kroos. And then sacking Ancelotti, one of the few managers in world football who can actually maintain a balance in a team full of overly expensive superstars.
But that’s been fairly typical of Real Madrid since 2009. Poor management, and a head-scratching transfer policy have led to that team accomplishing almost fuck all in the process.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body: Paolo: you’ve actually outlined the reasons why I’m personally coming to the view that Cuadrado would make an excellent RB. I’ve seen good defensive ability from him and I find that he’s much more effective offensively when he contributes less (i.e., quality vs quantity). Early in the season, it seemed he was being used as the main offensive creator — a role he’s proven ill-suited for — with very limited success. When he’s not used as the main guy, he’s got the ability to surprise and therefore contribute more effectively.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
From what we’ve seen this season, there is absolutely nothing to support the view that Cuadrado is "shitty" defensively. I’m not sure if he established that reputation before he came to us but I’ve seen no evidence of this this year.
For me, if you’re adequate defensively but can offer something interesting offensively, then that makes for a potentially great FB. I sense that many here place an inordinate amount of value of the defensive capabilities of the FB position but, for a team like Juve that should always be looking to outscore its opponents by margins of 2+, then it helps greatly to have offensive-minded FBs. Cuadrado fits the bill for me.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
I ask this in a very genuine and non-confrontational way: as long as we win, why is the clean sheet so important? We’ve got one of the top 3 goalies on earth and 4 or 5 CBs that other teams would die for; why not risk putting them to work more if the trade-off is more goals for us?
I’m definitely not suggesting we should play like riverboat gamblers, but I absolutely believe that for us to take the next step in Europe (i.e., consistently being among the favourites) we have to tilt the balance more in favour of offense. All the great teams score lots of goals; they couldn’t care less if they go a goal down because they know they’re going to score. I’m tired of losing to Sevilla and drawing twice with Moenchengladbach and, in prior years, losing to Olympiacos and Galatasaray. These are teams that must be punished and we’ve been too timid to do so.

Oh and i have to disagree completely with your statement all the great teams score lots of goals and didnt care if they go a goal down
How many cups have italy and juve won with superior defence?
Great teams won with good defence

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Title: Given that the statement was about "Europe", Juve's won two major trophies - which isn't a lot.
Comment Body:
Brazil and Germany, who historically play an incredibly offensive game, have more trophies than anyone else. Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, and Barcelona are three of the top five in UCL titles. Italy/Juve (combined) have won one major trophies since the late 80s. I’m not trying to diss Juventus or say they’re not great or anything like that, but trophies aren’t a great example.
It’s also pretty unrealistic to suggest you can only improve a position if you can improve both sides of it. This is an incredibly simplified example, but that’s like saying that if you’ve got a RB whose +2 offensively and +5 defensively it’d be foolish to replace him with someone that’s +10 offensively and +4 defensively – when any team on the planet would take an upgrade like that, given the chance.
Also, it’s incredibly hyperbolic to say that a switch from a fullback to a wingback puts you in the realms of Roma – especially in a 3-back formation, whose width is entirely derived from wingbacks.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
You are not a Juventus fan and will never understand how valued defence is for us.
Forgive me but i never had any wish to discuss anything with your Football Manager approach.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body: Germany historically offensive? Maybe if history began in 2006. You might also want to look up the history of the UEFA cup.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Title: Where Real, Barca, and Bayern are all in the top 4 of trophies won?
Comment Body:
But you’re completely missing the point. The point wasn’t, "attacking football is better than defensive football." The point was that one isn’t better than the other. Yes defensive teams have done well, but there are a lot (a lot) of trophies that go to very, very, very offensive minded teams. And there are a lot of offensive minded teams that have obliterated defensive minded teams head-to-head.
Has it worked the other way around? Absolutely, but that side of the argument was covered – so I didn’t feel the need to point it out.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
No, I corrected your assertion that Germany are "incredibly offensive" historically and your failure to recognise the UEFA cup as a major trophy. Until the admission of non-champions it was a harder competition.
Stop deliberately misconstruing what people say.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
but that’s like saying that if you’ve got a RB whose +2 offensively and +5 defensively it’d be foolish to replace him with someone that’s +10 offensively and +4 defensively
ofc no one is going to reject tht trade off. This trade off is similar to sandro for evra sandro is 9/10 offensive and 7 defensive while Evra is a 8 defensive and 7 offensive but diff between licht and cuadrado is licht is 4 offensive and 8 defensive and cuadrado is 7 offensive and 3 defensive so trade off is huge you hv to pick one of them cant hv two.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
Hang on a minute Semperty! There are so many errors in your statement it’s not funny. GB has already pointed out some of them.
First you say the discussion is about "Europe" but then mention Brazil in your first sentence.
Even comparing Brazil and Germany – Brazil have won 5 World Cups – only one more than Italy and Germany have the same – four. Until the last World Cup Italy were always ahead of Germany.
"Italy/Juve (combined) have won one major trophies since the late 80s."
Wrong. Italy and Juve have one two major trophies – 96 UCL and 2006 WC. Also Juve has won UEFA Cup during this period as well as other cups. And then Italy and Juve have been heavily well represented since the late 80s with some of the top records eg Juve have played in 5 UCL finals since then and Italy has had some outstanding performances like Runner up in WC and EC 1994, 2000, 2012 as well as 3rd at WC in 1990.
And we aren’t yet including Milan (and Inter God forbid) who have been heavily represented also during the period you referred to.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
Swapping a defensive player with an offensive one does not necessarily result in an overall more offensive style. One of the reason Mandzukic was bought was his work ethic when the team doesn’t have the ball. This is a man who leads our attack, yet what everyone acknowledge from him first and foremost is his contribution during the defensive phase of the game.
The word you’re looking for is "balance". The problem with Cuadrado is that he doesn’t have the intelligence of Lichtsteiner. Also, remember that the fullback sometimes need to tuck in and help mark the opposition’s striker when the ball is at the other flank. Do you believe Cuadrado can be disciplined enough to mark Insigne, Salah, Gervinho when they make diagonal runs into the box, trying to attack the space when Barzagli, Bonucci, and Chiellini had to slide to the left and help Evra?
A team play relies on trust. If his teammates in front of him don’t trust him during the defensive phase, they will subconsciously cover for him, and this will in turn dull their offensive contribution. Even with more offensive players on the pitch, you will end up with less offensive game. Khedira, who will likely play the MCR, will be more inclined to stay back. Dybala, who will become more isolated up top (because Khedira no longer support him as frequently as previously) will need to drop back more and get further away from goal. In turn Mandzukic will have to drop back as well for the same reason.
Of course, this would not happen if the team is ordered to play an unbalanced game. Look at Real Madrid, for example. They don’t care about the disconnect between the defensive units and the offensive ones. They don’t mind Marcelo running havoc, because they’re happy as long as they outscore the opponent. That’s why over a 50-games season, they get silly scorelines like 7-2, but also lose games quite a bit more frequently. And sometimes, they lose 0-4. Even Cannavaro struggled in Spain. How did they survive that long without "balance"? Easy, they have players like Ronaldo, James, Bale, Benzema, Kroos, Marcelo. Do we have that kind of players, or even the resources to attract those type of players? More importantly, is that the route that we want to take going forward?
In my view we shouldn’t compare which is more favourable between 1-0 and 4-2, for example. What we should do is compare the end game. Would you win more games, and with more consistency?

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
Offensive teams; Barcelona, Real Madrid, Bayern Munich, Man City, PSG, Arsenal, Dortmund, Napoli, Roma.
Defensive teams; Juventus, Atletico Madrid, Chelsea, Inter.
I think it’s fairly obvious that the game favours the more offensive teams. I’m not saying we should get rid of our "defensive" identity, but instead, try to balance things out. We’re lining up way too much defensive players on an already very defensive formation.
There’s no harm in playing Cuadrado as a WINGBACK, when Sandro, Chellini, Bonucci, Barzagli, Khedira, Marchisio and fucking Pogba are already starting.
One thing I also want to add, is the fact that everyone here is EXTREMELY underrating Cuadrado’s defensive contribution and abilities, you guys are treating him as a Dybala (defensively), when he’s a Pogba (defensively). He runs back harder than anyone in the whole team.
All the times he was substituted instead of Licht our team didn’t lose it’s defensive stability, but instead the right side of the team became much more involved in the attack, and the team possessed the ball more easily.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
Look, dude, I don’t see why you keep harping on about wanting to play "attacking" football so fucking much. All that matters is the RESULT. A beautiful, fluid 5-0 win? That’s fine by me. A grinded out, ugly, defensive 1-0 win? That’s also fine. I couldn’t care less about a crowd pleasing win. If fluid, attacking football won’t get us a result against, say, Bayern, then I really couldn’t care less about playing fluid, attacking football.
Just look at the teams in your list. Of the offensive teams you listed, only Barcelona, Real Madrid, Bayern, and maybe Dortmund have been successful in playing offensive football. The rest have accomplished fuck all in the Champions League using this offensive approach. Just look at Arsenal, they play fluid football, and guess who they were knocked out by in the CL last year? A Monaco side that was very defensively compact and organized. The same Monaco side that we had lots of difficulty breaking down.
Oh, and btw, are you aware that all of the defensive teams you listed have won the CL or reached the CL final using a defensive approach? Inter’s treble-winning side of 2010? Chelsea under Di Matteo in 2012? Atletico in 2014? And us last year? You like to talk about Italy’s achievements in the footballing world (and rightly so), and just look at them. They won 2 World Cups, and reached 2 World Cup finals using a defensive-minded approach. It’s hated, sure, but it gets RESULTS.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Title: An offensive game does allow for more variation.
Comment Body:
If you go out with the game plan to score 4 but allow 1, you’ve got wiggle room of a goal on either side of the ball. If you go out, and your objective is just to survive and advance with a 1-0 or 2-0, and something goes wrong on either side, you’re looking a 1 point instead of 3.
That’s not to say defense doesn’t work, but it really relies on perfection throughout the competition (match or season) – which is incredibly unlikely.

Comment Body:
It’s too simplistic to say that one is more important than the others. They all have a role to play. Buffon and Evra stirred the group when the going gets tough, Marchisio and Khedira add stability and balance to the team, Chiellini provided some grit and steel at the back, while Dybala and Mandzukic stepped up when Alvaro experienced difficult moments. You could even argue that Sandro added a new dimension to our offensive game which allowed other players like Pogba and Dybala to really exploit the oppositions’ defense.
If we’re strictly speaking about on the field contribution, then I think you all know that my pick would be Principino.

Comment Body:
But if BT Sports commentators cannot even pronounce Khedira’s name (Ke-die-rah? I mean seriously?), imagine the ’mare they will have with Mandragora xD (Mendrah-goora anyone? Called it here first!)
Concerning our MVP of the first half of the season, it’s gonna sound cheesy as fuck, but it has to be the team. Kinda like how they say in a relationship there is one lover, the other lover, and ‘us’ (the ‘third’ person), likewise in a team sport there are all the players, coaches, staff etc and the TEAM. The strength and unity that our collective unit showed during this turmoil, during this transitional period, was remarkable. It could have gone downhill real fast and real ugly (ooh hey there Chelsea FC!) but it didn’t and I’m ever so grateful that it did not. It was a huge test of character and a lesson to us all about honor, grinta, and the power of the collective.
Like I said, look at how ugly it got at Chelsea. That’s the difference between a team that has a collective unit and spirit and one that, quite frankly, does not.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
Sassulo today is not the same team that beat merda last week. They are missing critical players (Canavaro and Berardi) to suspension and once they lost Missiroli to injury their left side was further exposed. Hard to keep Napoli down but give Sassuolo credit for continuing to play an open game and attack most teams would have parked the bus and more.
Juve’s collaborative efforts with Sassulo has benefits for both clubs beyond player development and exchanges. Their management and business model (including ownership of the Mapei Stadium) represent the new wave in Serie A led by Juve. The resistance to change and modernization of the "traditional" bloc in FIGC should weaken as smaller teams follow the Sassulo model for growth.
Hopefully Di Francesco will take them in Europe. If that happens – in all likelihood Juve’s support and areas of collaborations will increase beyond youth development. It would be great to see their continued growth and the impact across the peninsula.

Article Title: Who was Juventus' MVP in the first half of the 2015-16 season?
Comment Body:
Especially with their fast, aggressive style of play is which is already showing grinding signs on some of the players. At the end of today’s game – even this early after the break – they slowed down quite a bit as exhaustion was reflected on a lot of their faces, leaving Sassuolo with a few chances to get back in. Chances better teams will make more of.
Now, combine that with the gap in quality between their first and second team, and their reasonable luck with injuries so far, and it likely becomes a matter of time before they slowly Roma.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
It seems we bid 15mil for Tielemans but Anderlecht rejected it. We are prepping to sign him in summer.
For those who don’t know him he is 18 year old can play anywhere in midfield dm/cm/am. He is a BEAST in FM and looks like tht irl based on what lil I saw of him. Potential wise he has imo as much as dybala and is most likely anderlecht’s best talent so far.
He is young but has some experience 17 matches in Belgium league and 6 apps in UEL.
I think beppe got hold of my FM wishlist first Cerri then Sandro now either Tielemans (would prefer him) or gundogan, sadly draxler got away. I wonder who he will go for next.

Comment Body: Any future transfers besides the long term investment in Italian youngsters will have to be acquisitions of quality starter level players. Mind you I dont believe any such move will be in this window. Besides utility squad players like Peluso et al buying expensive prospects regularly could cause a constant state of transition as witnessed at the start of the season. Its time we settle the squad and really push on domestically and importantly in Europe.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
Tielemans will only need to adapt to the league like gundogan will but experience especially european he has quite decent. I dont think he will hv trouble adjusting to the club as he seems to hv tht mentality and pressure wise he will be under less pressure than gundogan. If gundogan comes in he will be expected to dethrone one of Khedira or Marchisio and take their spot immediately while adjusting to the league. Tielemans will be allowed to slowly settle in like Sandro.
As I have said I dont mind either but Tielemans is a greater talent then gundogan and I am very positive he will hv sandro/dybala like impact on this squad that is within half season he is settled in and is an important player in the team. If there is a chance to get him we shd, his value will double like how dybala’s has within a season.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
If Juventus would buy Tielemans today he would have very difficult to make an impact like Sandro or Dybala.
At the moment he is a bench player at Anderlecht (coach Hasi prefers Defour and Dendoncker) and when he plays he is very inconsistent.
But I think that a change of environment would benefit Tielemans a lot. Rather in the summer so he can blend in before big games are played.
His mentality is great, he is really mature for his age and a club like Juventus would be ideal (certainly for me ;-)).
I think Tielemans will evolve as a regista in front of defense. But he can easily play in a Khedira or Pogba-role.
If Juventus will buy him I think they should make room for him. Lemina should be gone and maybe even Hernanes.

Well they are planning to get him in summer and I agree he will be a vice-marchisio. I feel given the time and how Allegri is with young talents he CAN have a sandro/dybala like impact or at least sturaro type for sure.
I didnt know he was bench player, whenever I saw him play he was startting, checking transfermarkt it seems he is being benched recently must hv missed tht been busy.
still for a 18 year old so far this season

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: I'm not sure I'd say he's unproven.
Comment Body: Over 650 minutes in Champions League play, almost 450 Europa League minutes this year on top of 160 minutes last year, and he’s been a big part of their European play at 17 and 18 years old. He’s calm, collected, creative, and probably my favorite type of player to bring off the bench. His floor makes him a good bench piece already, but he’s got potential to be absolutely immense – so you don’t lose a ton using him as a rotation piece but you could get all of the upside that he brings.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: tielemans is one of the hottest prospects in europe right now, signing him isn’t a bad idea at all.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: Bought him in my FIFA Career mode and turned him into the best midfielder in Europe. If that’s remotely a possibility, do it!

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: I was really hoping Barca would go after him, but he's absolutely a beast.
Comment Body:
He’s incredibly calm, he’s disciplined with his positioning, he can play in the hole or play deep, he’s got great vision, he’s creative – great package for someone his age. I also love the experience he brings for his age. He’s got over 660 minutes of Champions League play, and over 600 Europa League minutes on top of that (with potential for more in the Round of 32).
He’d definitely be a role player next season, but he’s not an unexperienced kid based on potential. He’d be a good role player as is, but has potential to be so much better.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
Hi, I’m also from Anderlecht.
Tielemans is certainly a star to be but he needs to develop further and that ain’t going to happen at Anderlecht (not a great team and the coach hasn’t a clue).
So he needs to move but a topclub like Juventus, Barça, etc. is too soon, I think and he will cost to much to loan him out to Sassuolo.
15M is a joke indeed, certainly if the English clubs are interested.
I don’t see Juventus spending big on a 18 year old who still needs time before he can make an impact.
On a side note: Praet will never be a star, maybe a decent player for a club like Fiorentina.
Dendoncker is lucky he can play for Anderlecht. It’s already a high level for a player with his abilities.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: Anyone read up about these Quagliarella rumors regarding his transfer away from Napoli to Juventus? I’ve only seen headlines and haven’t read the report yet.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
[Napoli president] Aurelio De Laurentiis sold me because he had received anonymous letters and phone messages accusing me of taking cocaine during house parties with Camorra Mafia members

I was forced to leave my hometown and Napoli sold me to Juventus. I had been falsely accused of being a Camorrist and a pedophile who was doing orgies. President De Laurentiis used to call me every day, but after those letters he advised to me to leave my hometown Castellammare di Stabia to go live in a hotel, to be more calm and relaxed.

After that conversation that took place in Napoli’s headquarters, he had never called me again.
From Quags on the stand in a recent court trial. Very odd. Still need to read up on it a bit.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: Wow, what the hell

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
OK – read more re: Quaglia and this very odd story.
The long quote I posted above is from a court trial that Fabio is currently brining against a former police officer that he accuses of stalking and harassing him.
Allegedly the cop wanted to become friend of Quagliarella. At first he succeeded,but then turned mental and became more and more obsessed
— Tancredi Palmeri (@tancredipalmeri) January 14, 2016

Not only am I SUPER suspicious of the claims made to Napoli’s president during Eta Beta’s time there (afterall, the police office does seem to have some sort of personal issue with Fabio), but I find it odd that despite this rumored activity and controversy, Fabio went on to have the most success of his career when he arrived at Juve.
Either way – I hope that Fabio can find a settled place to play without crazy, jilted ex-friends, nutso fans, or hyper-reactive owners sabotaging his chance for success. Always felt that he was a professional player with a killer instinct – I admire those kind of strikers.
Link.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
it seem of recent we have been linked or showed interest in several mid( CM, CAM, DM) and i think management wants to add a really top class mid with some attacking/offensive talent but because of mid season most players cup tied and there seems to be no sure date of when Pereyra will be back. Also not forget the cost of a really high class CAM (De Bruyne, James Rog., etc.) i think the beat option for Juve might be right under here " POGBA". For me he is the ideal candidate for this role, talent, skill, creativity and dribbling is already there, its just to harnest it to the fullest. There is always talk of how much he contributes in the midfeild but what if get someone who can give the same midfeild contributions as pogba. which brings me to Axel Witsel some here have mention his name and i also want to endorse it. I feel he would a perfect addition moving forward. If we were to aquire him i feel our midfeild would be the abosolute best in Italy an Europe and it wouldnt cost more than 18-25 when in reality you cant even buy top class CAM in this market for that money, farless pay their wages. Can I get some views on you guys /gals think. Also Asamoah can hold the forth for the reat of the season in UCL game until Pereyra comes back atleast at until next season.
My squad moving forward
Buffon
Lich Bon Cheillini Sandro
Khedera Marchiso Asa/Witsel
Pogba/Pereyra
Dybala Morata
This venture is an option since we more than likely will be out bided for all the tip CAM talent by the impending super rich EPL.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: How do u solve a problem like Roma
Comment Body: Having conceded a lot of of goals this season, it seems they need an authoritative centre back to play with Manolas and a new right back as Florenzi isnt a natural full back. While they have the 3rd best attack in the league with 36 goals behind Fiorentina and Napoli with 37 and 38 respectively they still need another striker as Dzeko has managed to score only 3 league goals and 5 in all comps. I understand he he suffered some niggly injuries but that is not a good tally for championship challenging side. A back up winger for Salah and Gervinho won’t be a bad idea either. I doubt all these areas will be attended to in this transfer window. Perhaps Spalletti will be able to motivate the squad to overcome such shortcomings. Either way theres a lot of work to be done most important of all being a change in the clubs mentality.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
Needs: CF, CB, RB
I really could see Roma putting bids in for Bruno Peres or Mimmo Criscito. That would solve their fullback issue and, in the case of that damned tank Peres, solve the problem with an eye for the future.
The CB issue is more interesting. I have seen murmurs of an interest in retaining the services of Mehdi Benatia if they can pry him away from Pep and Bayern. Unlikely, yes. Moreover, it goes to show how little of a plan their management actually have if they truly are inquiring about a transfer of the Moroccan.
Frankly, I don’t know how they will solve the CF issue. They simply need more experience and guile in their attack if they plan on vying for a top 3 spot – which is looking more and more difficult every day given the superb play of their direct rivals for those positions (Napoli, Juve, Fiorentina, Inter).

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: Bruno Peres will be an excellent buy for them. As for Domenico Criscito, i always thought it was a shame when he never got a chance at Juve but haven’t followed him since. He was part of that generation with Chiello, Balzaretti, Giovinco and Marchisio.What i do know is that he offers versatility in terms of LB and CB. I would think the rumours currently circulating are for him being deployed at CB as Digne has done too badly.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: Criscito and Spalletti have a history together from the Tuscan’s time in charge of Zenit, where Mimmo currently and oddly still plays.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
On CB the thing is they have continually sold their best CB every season and I wont be surprised if Manolas is sold at the end of this season (really like him one of the fastest CB in current game) but true Sabatini is looking very foolish now. Castan has been injured to often, if not Castan – Manolas pairing was good + coz of the meh FBs the CBs get dragged out of position to make them looks worse than they are. Example Juve under Del Neri and Juve under conte, with better FBs and better tactics same CBs were awesome.
They definitely need an RB Florenzi is being wasted there he might be doing decent job to impress some ppl but he can do sooo much more as a winger/midfield.
on CF I think as long as they get anyone barring a winger they would be good. Roma in recent history seems to be winger crazy like wenger is AM crazy, something is wrong? lets fix it with winger. They dont need SES when they hv Gervinho, Salah, Florenzi and Iago (this one is a lol). Right now more than Dzeko I feel they are missing someone like Totti.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
I think their CB pairs (and even back-up) are very very good, certainly the second best after Juventus in Serie A. Manolas is an amazing player, then you have Castan and Rudiger who both have the talent.
As for the fullback, Florenzi has been performing very well there, true he’s offensive, but that doesn’t mean he’s shit defensively. Now back to what they have horrible defence, it’s because of Garcia’s tactics, they have the talent but the defensive tactics are absolute shit. Leading to them losing with 7’s and 6’s very easily.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
Conceeding 22 goals in 19 games is poor. So far as their CB’s go, Castan has never convinced, Vaniqueur is shit and i concede that Rudiger has potential but far too often looks shaky. Don’t get me started on Norbert Gyomber too. This is the sum of a poor transfer market operation from the Roma hierarchy as well as poor tactical discipline from Garcia. Hopefully Roma can surprise us all by upsetting RM for the sake of serie A coefficients but alas that may be a bridge too far.
In other news there is talk of a return of Franco Baldini…

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: 1.15 goals per 90 minutes is not poor.
Comment Body: Not by any means. If it is, ~75% of Serie A has really shitty defense.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: That is a good ratio for mid table side. It is poor comparatively for any top side with aspirations for the league title or champs league. In fact Roma are the worst for number of goals conceded among the top six in Serie A. To give you an idea, last season Juve conceded 24 in our march to the title. At this rate Roma will be conceding over 40 goals come the end of the season which is only desirable for a Europa league chasing side.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: If "bad" defense gets you a Europa League spot
Comment Body: Serie A is far, far worse than anyone is suggesting.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: I believe my point is valid when considered in relation to Roma. For a club of their side with aspirations to win the scudetto, the current performance of their defence is insufficient. I’m sure many would be concerned if we shipped that amount of goals. Any scudetto triumph is launched on the back of a good defence. Talking about Roma, I havent even mentioned their defensive record in the champs lge this season where they have conceded 16 goals in just 6 games. Come on you can’t deny there is a problem with their defensive stats.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: Funny, because Roma is one of the few Serie A clubs that play in a non-Italian way, hence why their defence sucks. Now with a different manager they might change.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: Again, if 1.15 goals per game is bad defense
Comment Body: There are literally only 3 or 4 good defenses in Serie A (unless that 1.15 mark is some oddly specific number – then the number jumps all the way up to….5 good defenses). I’m not saying they’ve got a good defense. I’m not saying they’ve got a great defense. I’m just saying they currently sit sixth in goals conceded in Serie A. If that’s a defense that "sucks," Serie A as a whole is miserably bad.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
I’m obviously comparing them to the strongest teams in Serie A, not the whole league. Of course their defence compared to the whole league is above average, that’s because they’re easily in the top 5 teams of the league.
Napoli, Juventus, Fiorentina, and Inter all have better defence, even Sassuolo has a better defence. See the problem?

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: They've got the fourth best goal differential in Serie A
Comment Body: So no, I really don’t see the issue. I mean, I see the issue is that fans don’t like the departure from an incredibly defensive game, but at the end of the day the objective is to score more than your opponents, and Roma does that better than everyone but Napoli, Juve, and Fiorentina (at least, thus far).

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: It’s all relative man. Look at their personnel compared to Sassuolo’s. They should have a way better defensive record than them. Also they were favorites along with Juve for the scudetto at the beginning of the season so yes it is bad for them. You’re right that differential is probably a better judgement than strictly defensive stats alone, but even then they are in 4th in serie A, which doesn’t live up to expectations, and when looking at all comps it drags it down quite a bit

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
As it stands we have acquired some excellent prospect to carry on beyond Chiello, Buffon and Marchisio. Of course its great to have young talents such Pogba, Dybala and Morata but foreign players are always likely to leave in the future when the big offers come along.
More reassuring are the young Italian players in the clubs longterm plans such as Nicola Leali, Filippo Romagna, Domenico Berrardi, Sturraro, Daniele Rugani, Stefano Sensi and Rolando Mandragora. Importantly these are youngster who are getting regular games at their respective clubs at present with the exception of those at Juventus at present. Their experience with the club are equally important if not more so.
The future of the Azzurri certainly looks black & white.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
Say what you want about Hernanes but he just made a pretty awesome comment to Paolo Aghemo (Sky Sport) in an interview today.
What strikes you as special about Juventus as a squad?

I saw that Edgar Davids mentioned that it was at Juve where he learned to win. I also saw an explanation from reading a book by Bruce Lipton, a scientist, who said that while doing an experiment with cells, he noticed that wherever you placed the cells, they changed and adapted to their environment. That is what strikes me about Juventus as a squad – the atmosphere is so strong when you arrive that you change your way of thinking, your cells become completely bianconero. The Juventus atmosphere is that special, that successful that we feel alive.

Article Title: Report: Monday medical set for soon-to-be Juventus signee Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: Some kind words for Juve from a former Giak of all trades
Comment Body:
Re: his relationship with Conte:
The mister is one who looks at who the man is before he considers his quality on the pitch. He won a lot in his career yet still has hunger for more. He absolutely despises losing. I think that it totally makes sense that Juve won so much with him as their manager.
Re: Juve specifically:
As soon as I arrived at Juve, I could sense the scent of victory. If you dont win, it’s a total failure. Every year, this expectation of victory resets itself.
Glad to see the guy not only return to Italy after his British nightmare, but also succeeding with Bologna – he even scored a late goal against Milan a few rounds ago to bring home the 3 pts. Hope his successes continue, just never against Juve.

Comment Body: Great stuff and very consistent with what Hernanes just said and many others before them. It’s what makes Juve great. I also agree it’s great seeing Giak doing well.

Article Title: Reports: Juventus complete deal with Genoa for midfielder Rolando Mandragora
Comment Title: I would start him at Juve now, yes.
Comment Body: But there’s still a big difference in expected performance from Juve’s starters and Real Madrid’s starters. At this point in time, I’d argue that none of Juve’s forwards would be expected starters in Real, Barca, or Bayern. There’s nothing wrong with that, those three are just a step above everyone else in what’s expected.

Article Title: Reports: Juventus complete deal with Genoa for midfielder Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
If you want to say Morata isn’t currently as good as the starters for those teams, I think nearly everyone would agree with you. In fact I’m pretty sure you rate Morata more highly than I do. But that’s different than saying he’s not ready to start for them. The expectations for all these teams is to win the domestic league (and push for the cup), and to make a legitimate challenge for the CL.
Basically what I’m saying is that saying someone isn’t ready to start for a team implies they aren’t yet good enough to play at that level, and Juventus and Madrid are playing at the same level (ie legitimately fighting for the major silverware).
I’m going to stop since reading over this I feel like I’m arguing too fine a point and it seems almost petty. BTW I like that Holmes quote, and it reminds me of the Mentats in Dune.

Comment Title: OT: But I found this one interesting.
Comment Body:
. @JongsmaJongsma analyses non-defensive actions in relation to pitch location. https://t.co/r4FBoyqjLE. Build-up. pic.twitter.com/RQVhCGZBZN
— OptaPro (@OptaPro) January 14, 2016

Basically, there’s no central defense in Spain or France, no wide defense in Italy or Germany, no defense until the final third in England, and just no defense in Belgium or the Netherlands. At least, that’s the pessimistic way of looking at it. You could say, there’s a lot of wide defense in Spain and France, a lot of central defense in Italy, great defense in the final third in England, and….no defense in Belgium or the Netherlands.

Article Title: Reports: Juventus complete deal with Genoa for midfielder Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body:
But it basically says there’s a lot more than average play on the wings in Spain and a lot more than average play centrally in Germany and Italy. I just took the extra step in assuming that the defense happened where the play happened.
I don’t know what it means for Italy, as I can’t really answer hant’s question. I don’t know if this goes one direction, or if it’s free-flowing.

Article Title: Reports: Juventus complete deal with Genoa for midfielder Rolando Mandragora
Comment Body: Rumours of us making a move for the Monaco attacking mid seem to be picking up steam. Based on highlights video review, it’s easy to see why: fast, good dribbler and passer, and a surprisingly tenacious defender for an offensive player. He doesn’t seem to have the jaw-dropping offensive capabilities of an Isco but brings the type of balance that our management really seems to value. We’ve been linked with a number of attacking mids since Max joined but this one feels like there could be something to it. Silva’s young, likely not wildly expensive (transfer fee and salary) and seems to be a good fit both for Europe and Serie A. Someone to keep an eye on!

Article Title: Reports: Juventus complete deal with Genoa for midfielder Rolando Mandragora

Article Title: A Black and White Resurgence: How Juventus got back into the Scudetto race
Comment Body:
I hate to admit it, but the 352.
That’s how we got back into the Scudetto race. The 352 with Licht on RWB and Marchisio on regista. Not Mandzukic per se, not Cuadrado, not the zona mista.
Of course, having Dybala also helped a ton, and also Pogba going back to LCM free-roam.

Article Title: A Black and White Resurgence: How Juventus got back into the Scudetto race
Comment Title: We were never out of the race...
Comment Body: … after a very long season last season our players mutually agreed and a decision was made to have a couple months more off to do basically nothing also to give the perennial moaners a head start. At least we cant be faulted for giving everyone a chance.

Article Title: A Black and White Resurgence: How Juventus got back into the Scudetto race
Comment Title: Here's how we got back into the scudetto race...
Comment Body:
by winning.
on a more serious note, the first two months, while disastrous in result, was a consequence of a plan that is clearly looking into the end-game. I for one am glad they stick to it and not panic and make drastic changes. as a result, the whole team is looking integrated, wins picking up, and as of now, back as favourites for the title.

Article Title: A Black and White Resurgence: How Juventus got back into the Scudetto race
Comment Body:
We got back into the title race because their are not as many injuries to our key players. In the start of the season we had a midfielder three of Pogba, Sturaro and Padoin, now we have Khedira, Marchisio and Pogba. The three main players for our revival have been:
1) Pogba- He started of poor but I don’t blame him, he was surrounded by crap but as his form started to improve so did the team and he is back to his brilliant best!
2) Dybala- He has been incredible and his magic has given us three points on more than one occasion with that Milan goal being an example.
3) Marchisio- Not much to say except we looked seriously lost without him, when he returned so did our form!

Article Title: A Black and White Resurgence: How Juventus got back into the Scudetto race
Comment Body: Juve also hasn’t lost when Khedira plays. He’s another Marchisio in the sense that he flies under the radar but does great work for the team

Article Title: A Black and White Resurgence: How Juventus got back into the Scudetto race
Comment Body:
I think our resurgence was:
1. Getting key players back from injury especially Marchisio.
2. Allegri stopping fucking about and making more consistent player and formation choices especially the trusted 3-5-2 (fortunately we had added bite in the wingback category this year especially with Sandro)
3. The slow emergence of Dybala which was inevitable and Mandzukic finding form which was probably also inevitable (I don’t include Pogba here cos he was always good just too much pressure on his shoulders he was expected to do too much when players were out).
4. The natural progression of time for a new squad with players learning confidence in one another.

I guess, for me, it’s just that Max is clearly so smart. He’s shown the ability to put together a gameplan that allows his teams to beat superior teams. He showed this with Milan (who gave Barca all they could handle) and with us last year vs Madrid. I just haven’t seen the same ability from Montella yet.
And I did notice your choice of the word "prefer". It’s perfectly reasonable for you to prefer Montella’s style of play and I won’t attempt to change your mind. But when it comes to winning, I can’t see a logical argument for wanting Montella over Max (and it’s not like Max doesn’t play nice football, even if I too would rather he be less conservative).

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
If I could give Hernanes one tip that would keep him in a Juve shirt, it would be "Know your place".
He is a good player, good technique, good shooting with both feet and not too shabby vision. Only, he’s no Pirlo and he’s no super-duper CAM no more. I don’t think he ever was, to be honest. He had a good stint with Lazio but inconsistency is his biggest flaw, because he always tries to do too much.
Whenever he tries to do too much, he fails miserably.
He needs to stay within the confines that allow him to play comfortably, bringing his stronger attributes into play, and the rest will follow.
I think he understands now what he needs to do in order for him to play better in a team. If youse no team player you will always find it hard to fit in at our club.
He never had to be a team player before. The Samp game was a big step for him as a Juve player.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body: While he did some good things, I think any praise Hernanes is receiving is because the bar is just so low. He’s clearly got some ability but his defense is very poor, he had some giveaways and overall just doesn’t appear to be Juve quality. When healthy, it would be nice to see Lemina possibly grab the vice-Marchisio role but my preferred choice would be Khedira. I just think he has all the required attributes (poise, composure, intelligence, defense, etc.) and, when Khedira and Marchisio play at the same time, it would provide an opportunity for them to swap positions in-game. Max always talks about not giving "reference points" to the opposition and creating fluidity between Marchisio’s and Khedira’s roles would certainly help in this regard.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
He was the best player in Lazio for several years, and was rarely inconsistent. He was stripped from his "home" for money before his contract expired, and left Lazio rather unwillingly.
Maybe Inter didn’t work with him well, and maybe we do (although I’ve seen us done our fair share of treating players badly). But based on statistics that could actually be captured on whoscored, he was the second best player on the pitch against Sampdoria. Look at the trend; great stats in Lazio, abysmal in Inter. If we manage our resources well, and if fans actually get behind their playes, we have a winner at our hands.
In my opinion, you guys should be ashamed of yourselves. Some of the jaded "regulars" and a bunch of negative newcomers. If you guys had been around during ADP’s horrific injury crisis where he was forced to reinvent his pace game, that would mean we won’t have Il Capitano in our team. Remember when Buffon replaced Storari? He was nowhere near Storari for an entire season, but we gave him the chance to regain his game. Marchisio has been blamed of being invisible since Del Neri during the LM days, and still carries that title from the fans here, yet his absence is the MOST felt compared to any other player on the pitch. Get behind your team and leave this tabloid fanboyish nonsense where it belongs; in the EPL and La Liga for God’s sake.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
Comparing Hernanes to ADP is a bit of a stretch.
We could debate this all day long but this season Hernanes performance from a technical standpoint has been poor.
I haven’t followed him in the past and by all accounts he was very good at Lazio. But that was the past. I can only judge him in current performance and he consistently looks out of his depth this season. For one thing his short passing game and decision making has been poor. In tight situations he just doesn’t know what to do and turns the ball over easily or puts enormous pressure on the person he passes to.
Second half v Samp he was much better but this was when the game was more open and less pressure on him. This shows he can play – some nice passes etc. And all throughout the game he made some nice interceptions. And he always has had a good shot and freekick.
But the job of the regista is to control possession and the game for his team. Hernanes has not showed this ability. He has looked very clumsy and awkward on the ball when the game is tight, tough and the pressure’s on.
I don’t trust him, especially against better teams and important matches. I’d still be very happy to seem him leave and would prefer Lemina when fit (or a new midfielder) as the back up to Marchisio.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
but fans can only see what’s on the field to make their judgement. And for those players who prove the fans wrong, there are also those who were given many chances only to still end up a flop. If mandzukic still hasn’t scored to this day (remember his droughts in the first few months? anyone?), given our depth in striker position, should we be condemned for wanting him to be dropped to give someone else a go? By definition this is getting behind your team, even if some individuals will inevitably suffer.
And I think you overestimate the effect of fans’ attitude on players performances. To your ADP example; fans aren’t coaches nor transfer directors, therefore no matter how much the fans react negatively to his post-injury form ADP would’ve still stayed, and then prove those fans wrong and won the affection over again. Fans will always have opinion, though I’m glad our board are those who with quite confidence knows what they’re doing and won’t be swayed by popular thoughts, unlike RM.
And are we always the fickle type? I don’t know… For morata’s lack of goals all of us here still supports him. If you look at fans of other teams (even in serie A) I see this blog is still generally the more reasonable types.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body: What’s a Del Neri?

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
Ashamed? Please. The fans here are more than happy to show patience towards players going through a rough spell: Buffon, Chiellini, Morata, Mandzukic – as long one can see they’re trying hard and there’s cause for hope. Morata for example, for all I care he could fail to score till the end of this season and I’d still be saying we should keep him and trust him. Same for Llorente last season: how many off-color performances did we tolerate because we knew he was trying hard and he had a likeable personality?
Hernanes provides no such glimpses of hope. He’s been dead rubber for 2 years now. Nothing against him on a personal level but he’s been given countless chances which he has not taken and he doesn’t even try.
You should be ashamed for being so over-dramatic and comparing Hernanes to bandiere like Buffon and del Piero and having this "You’re either with us or against us" Mourinho-like mentality. We’re talking about a football player’s performances here, it’s not a man being stoned to death or threatened. Of course criticism is allowed… where does this "he’s our player therefore you can’t criticise" mindset come from?

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
The fact that Juve is snatching these young kids with the help of Sassuolo bodes well for all parties, Juve, Sassuolo, the youngsters and the Italian national team. Juve will have the right to first refusal, Sassuolo will remain afloat and in Serie A, something they will find it hard to maintain for a longer period of time by themselves, these youngsters will have an extra motivation/goal driving them on—the dream of one day donning the sacred black and white. And a strong Italian dominated Juve can only lead to one thing; a brighter future for the Azzurri
That’s all fine and dandy but none of that makes me as happy as this…..

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body: A team like Juventus must have better players than Hernanes. Ok, Hernanes regista somewhat worked against Sampdora. Would it work against Bayern? Barcelona? RM? Obviously not. That’s always the problem. If Marchisio is unavailable for the league, well, we can survive with Hernanes (unless we play against Napoli). But should he be unavailable for CL, we would probably be fucked. And that’s not something that should happen in a team like Juventus. Every position that is crucial (like the regista position in the 3-5-2) should be covered by two high-quality players. And Hernanes isn’t. So I hope at the end of this season we say thank you and send him away, replacing him with Gundogan or someone of that level.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Title: I feel like a formation based around a 10 is just asking for a deep-lying playmaker.
Comment Body: The only way I can think of that avoids that issue is to play with a four and two 6’s in a 4-3-3. Anything else, you’re forcing your regista (the position referred to when talking about a deep-lying playmaker) into a deep position. It might work in a 4-1-2-1-2, with an out-and-out 4, two 6’s, and a 10.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
2009
the league was much stronger back then than it is now
Am I crazy here or does that strike anyone else as wildly incorrect? The campionato this season is an incredibly tight race with the 4 top teams separated by only 3 pts. Juventus seems poised continentally (finally) while the teams in Europa are capable and also playing well.
In 2009, there were obvious and lingering side effects still from calciopoli. I wouldnt say it was remotely stronger back then.
As for Spalletti – I don’t think Im too worried. For all of the admiration and love he seems to receive from Roma fans (who are undoubtedly excited today at yet another firing of a wayward manager and his replacement but yet another savior du jour), Spalletti’s time in Rome wasn’t really a resounding success. Despite the seriously weakened field of competitors (as a result of calciopoli), he managed 2 Coppa Italia victories, a Supercoppa, and 2 Second Place finishes (one in which he was more than 20 pts off of Inter in first). He performed somewhat well in the UCL – i.e. didnt get slapped around like Garcia did by the big boys and even beat RM over 2 legs. Otherwise, he was the beneficiary of a very fortunate situation on the peninsula at the time. Does anyone really think that he will be able to not only right the ship in Roma while simultaneously clawing back up the table in direct competition with this year’s Fiorentina, Napoli, Inter and Juve? I sure dont.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
Am I crazy here or does that strike anyone else as wildly incorrect? The campionato this season is an incredibly tight race with the 4 top teams separated by only 3 pts. Juventus seems poised continentally (finally) while the teams in Europa are capable and also playing well.
Not really. Inter and Milan were much stronger back then than they are now. Inter had Ibra, Lucio, Zanetti, Maicon, Cambiasso, etc., whereas Milan had Inzaghi, Seedorf, Kaka, Pirlo, Gattuso, etc. Juventus still finished 2nd despite having a pretty average squad (cause, y’know, post-Calciopoli). Not to mention Serie A still had four Champions League spots.
And the only reason the campionato is so tight this season is because we had such a horrible start to the season.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
That same Milan squad was hit by calciopoli as well – saddled with heavy fines and punishment, albeit not nearly as severe as Juve’s initial relegation to Serie C (reduced on appeal).
As well, the 4th UCL spot that Italy recently ‘lost’? It was taken away as a direct result of those teams’ poor performance in Europe (Inter in 2009-10, aside). The fact that they HAD 4 teams in UCL in that era is more indicative of the period preceding (pre-calciopoli) since coefficient is calculated with past results not expectation of future performance.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body:
what a time that was though. 06-08 for both man united and Roma, what a time. Both were in my top three teams of all time. I loved the way spalletti played that team, it was beautiful to watch. Not stupid and reckless like zeman, and not boring by any means. Totti in his prime flanked by mancini and a young vucinic, incredible. Extremely hot and cold team, but when they were hot, they were hot, just ask Chelsea and real Madrid.
And that man united side? ferdinand in his prime, van der sar the best keeper in the EPL, ronaldo, evra, class of 92 coming in at that near perfect amount of talent and experience (giggs, scholes, neville), not to mention solksjaer’s last season, and larsson… that’s a tough team to play.
Perfect example of spalletti’s roma blowing cold though. What an emotional team. That emotion & passion is needed in rome though, expect spalletti to bring some beautiful calcio back to the capital, whether successful or not in challenging for the scudetto, they’re going to be so enjoyable to watch again.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all
Comment Body: Fully expect spalletti to be there long term (hope more than expect). absolutely love the way the guy plays, it really just depends on if he can have the players he needs for his system (which they do) and if they’ll be selling off his best players every year. That’s what happened before, the club was in dire straits when he left. It really just depends on James’s expectations, which we’ll see soon enough, depending on what he says after spalletti finishes the season. What I want to see is flexibility, beautiful football, and a resurgence of totti. I’m very excited by spalletti, not because of season expectations, table finishes, wins, etc. I’m excited by it because I’m a romantic, which is the most important thing with roma, in my opinion. I don’t see the honeymoon ending if the team plays with passion and plays beautifully. the fans and curva turned on garcia because he kept putting 11 turds on the field and telling them to do the same thing every week and not impress anyone. Roma could definitely handle not being in european competition for a year (at most is my guess), but I don’t know how the season will end, it’s been a really weird season in serie a all around, but I also don’t think anyone is expecting spalletti to be a magic shot to fix everything immediately. He’ll at least be given 2016, at a minimum.

Article Title: Hernanes just might carve out a role at Juventus after all

Thank you. Very informative. I would like to see Roma getting back on track and representing Serie A properly and strongly. Hopefully this will begin this year and with Real. That collapse was indicative of a coaching failure that can not be shored up with $$$ and best playersb in the world. A strong Roma makes Juve better and winning the scudetto more meaningful, and ultimately helps Italy regain the lost European slot.
